It's great that you want to support your friend during a difficult time. Here are some steps you can take to help him: 1. **Communicate Openly:** Start an honest conversation with him. Let him know you’re concerned and that you're there for him. Sometimes just having someone to talk to can help. 2. **Encourage Small Changes:** Suggest small, manageable changes to his routine. This could include going for a walk, trying a new hobby, or even cooking a meal together. Small steps can help build momentum. 3. **Limit Passive Activities:** Encourage activities that require more engagement than watching movies or scrolling through the phone. This can include playing games, going for hikes, or visiting local attractions. 4. **Be Active Together:** Physical activity can help improve mood. Whether it's going to the gym, taking a dance class, or simply taking a walk outside, physical movement can be beneficial for mental health. 5. **Explore New Interests:** Introduce him to new hobbies or interests that can spark enthusiasm. This could be anything from creative arts to sports, depending on what might interest him. 6. **Set Goals Together:** Help him set small, achievable goals. These can be anything from completing a book to exercising a few times a week. Celebrating small achievements can provide a sense of purpose. 7. **Encourage Professional Help:** If his feelings of anger and lack of motivation persist, it might be beneficial for him to speak to a mental health professional. You can encourage him gently by letting him know that seeking help is a sign of strength. 8. **Be There:** Sometimes just being present can make a difference. Spend time together and be patient as he works through his feelings. 9. **Involve Other Friends:** If he is comfortable, consider involving other friends in activities. A social circle can provide support and distraction. 10. **Practice Self-Care:** Make sure to take care of yourself in the process as well. Supporting someone else can be emotionally taxing, so ensure you have your own support system and ways to recharge. Every individual is different, so be patient and understanding as he navigates his feelings. Your support can be invaluable during this time.

It can be really challenging when a family member, especially a parent, doesn't understand your boundaries or needs regarding sensitive topics like mental health. Here are some steps to consider that might help you communicate your feelings more effectively and establish boundaries: 1. **Choose the Right Time**: Find a calm moment to talk to your mother when you’re not in the middle of an argument. This can help set a more constructive tone for the conversation. 2. **Use "I" Statements**: When expressing your feelings, use "I" statements to help her understand your perspective. For example, you might say, "I feel overwhelmed when we talk about my depression, and I really need some time to process my feelings on my own." 3. **Set Clear Boundaries**: Be direct about your boundaries. Let her know that you appreciate her concern, but you don’t want to discuss your depression right now. You could say, "I understand you want to help, but I need some space regarding this topic. Can we talk about something else?" 4. **Explain Your Needs**: Help her understand that everyone deals with mental health differently. You could mention that opening up about your depression can be difficult, and it’s okay to take time for yourself. 5. **Offer Alternatives**: If she’s trying to connect with you, suggest other topics or activities that can foster a positive interaction without delving into your depression. This can help shift the focus away from the subject that causes tension. 6. **Seek Professional Help**: If conversations continue to lead to conflicts, consider seeking help from a therapist. You could suggest family therapy, which can create a safe space for both of you to express your feelings and improve communication. 7. **Reinforce Your Boundaries**: If she continues to push the topic despite your requests, it might be necessary to firmly reiterate your boundaries. Consistency is key; sometimes, it takes repetition for people to respect your needs. 8. **Practice Self-Care**: Make sure you’re taking care of yourself emotionally. Engage in activities that help you cope with depression, and consider talking with a friend or therapist who can provide the support you need. Remember that it’s okay to prioritize your mental health and to protect your emotional well-being in relationships. It may take time for your mother to understand your perspective, but staying firm and clear about your boundaries is important.

Hello,While one can be sad from time to time, feeling sad "all the time" could be a sign of depression. If you feel sad on most days, it is worthwhile speaking to a psychologist to determine whether you suffer clinical depression. Feeling sadness is a normal response to loss, whether you lose a family, friend, job, or something you deem important in your life. However, feeling sadness all the time is a signal that you are not happy about something in your life. If it is related to your family and often relationship with family members could affect our self-esteem and self-worth, then perhaps it is worthwhile exploring what you find unhappy about your relationship with your family. Is it that you do not feel heard, supported or loved? Is it that you feel disrespected, disregarded or feel unimportant? These are just a few examples of common issues that people report that contribute to their depression. To help you to uncover your reasons for your sadness or depression and to cope with them in a healthier and more constructive way, it may be helpful to contact a therapist who could support you with this process. You do not have to deal with it alone. Dr. Virginia Chow, Montreal Psychologist. For more information about depression, please consult my website at www.PsychologyResource.ca

Thank you for posting. I'm interested to hear some more information; such as, if you live by yourself or family, if you go to school/employed/unemployed, and what kind of things do you like to do with friends or by yourself. Often times, when we are experiencing a strong emotion that we interpret as negative, we put most of our focus on that negative emotion and struggle to see that we do not always feel that specific emotion. There are typically points in the day (even if it is for only in 1 minute intervals) when we do not feel that negative emotion. When we overgeneralize, we use words like "always" or "never" and when we use those words and it may not be totally true, we feel the negative emotion based on an inaccuracy which is not fair to you. Ask yourself some of these questions: Am I being realistic when I'm overgeneralizing things? Have I ever noticed a short period of time that I wasn't feeling anxious? What do I notice when I am feeling anxious? What am I thinking about? When was the last time I felt empathy? What was different when I was able to feel empathy? Hopefully this helps get you started.

Hello. So, someone made you happy but is no longer around? I am sure that feels devastating. As a counselor I usually have to ponder this kind of thought because it lends itself to suggesting that happiness comes from the external, rather than the internal side of a person's life. Happiness is formed within ourselves. All the external trappings of happiness are usually quite fleeting, and temporary. Even relationships fo not last forever. If we get to a place where we are reliant and dependent on those around us to create happiness in our lives, then we lose the opportunities for us to do it ourselves. We are entirely capable of finding ways to be happy. Sometimes this entails working out issues that are holding us back from reaching a place of peace, or resolution to a specific problem.What I would offer to you, is to find ways in which you can develop happiness for yourself. What do you like about your life as it is right now? What can you do to create change in your life to increase your happiness? These kinds of questions can be valuable to you as you seek out ways to make happiness an internal rather than an external event. Mourning the loss of a social connection (in whatever way that occurred), is part of the grieving process, but it is not permanent. It is a path to healing and moving forward. From this, you can seek out new sources of happiness. I encourage you to remember that happiness is independent of the external experience you have in the world. Happiness is an expression of the internal feelings, so that will be the source or the font of positive emotion from which you really draw. If you are lacking in happiness, then it becomes important to examine why that is, and what you can do about it to promote self-care. Seeking out a professional counselor can also be a good option as you move through the grief/loss process and examine the reasons happiness is not in greater supply.I wish you happiness for every day of your life.Best wishes.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. Losing people who bring joy to our lives can be incredibly challenging. Here are some suggestions that might help you navigate this difficult time and cultivate your own happiness: 1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**: Allow yourself to feel sadness and grief. It's natural to miss those who brought you happiness. Journaling about your emotions or talking to a supportive friend can help you process your feelings. 2. **Revisit Happy Memories**: Reflect on the good times you shared with those you’ve lost. This can help you appreciate the positive impact they had on your life while recognizing that it's okay to miss them. 3. **Create New Routines**: Establishing new daily routines can provide structure and a sense of stability. Incorporate activities that you enjoy or want to try, like reading, exercising, or learning a new skill. 4. **Engage in Self-Care**: Prioritize activities that promote your physical and mental well-being. This could include regular exercise, proper nutrition, meditation, or enjoying nature. 5. **Connect with Others**: While it may be difficult to seek new connections, consider joining clubs or groups that align with your interests. Engaging with new people can help you discover new sources of happiness. 6. **Explore Hobbies**: Dive into hobbies or interests that you may have set aside. Cultivating new passions can bring joy and help you focus on personal growth. 7. **Limit Negative Thoughts**: Practice mindfulness or meditation to help manage negative feelings. Techniques such as deep breathing or grounding exercises can help you stay present and minimize overwhelming emotions. 8. **Seek Professional Help**: If you're finding it particularly hard to cope, consider talking to a therapist or counselor. They can offer guidance and coping strategies tailored to your situation. 9. **Explore Gratitude**: Try to cultivate gratitude for the positive aspects of your life, however small. Keeping a gratitude journal can shift your focus towards the good things, even amid sadness. 10. **Allow Time**: Healing takes time. Be gentle with yourself and recognize that it's okay to feel sad. Over time, you may find new sources of happiness and fulfillment. Remember that it's perfectly normal to feel lost after the loss of significant people in your life. Give yourself grace during this process, and take it one day at a time. You are not alone in this journey.

It is hard to make a definite diagnosis however I would say that it could be and or a combination of depression, stress, PTSD, etc. More background information would have to be needed. One thing I would say is that you really need to seek guidance from a professional to work through these symptoms. If what you described as a caged animal is released, all the crying, sadness, and controllable emotions will come out. That would not be good when they do. Get help before they do..

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of inner turmoil while trying to maintain a calm exterior. Feelings of being emotionally distant but simultaneously feeling an intense, unidentifiable emotion can be quite disconcerting. The metaphor of being a "caged animal" suggests a sense of confinement or frustration, which can come from various sources—stress, unresolved feelings, or even a lack of fulfillment in certain areas of life. Here are a few things you might consider to help process what you're experiencing: 1. **Identify the Emotion**: It might help to explore what the internal screaming represents. Could it be frustration, anxiety, or a need for freedom or change? Journaling or talking to someone you trust can sometimes help clarify these feelings. 2. **Physical Outlet**: Engaging in physical activity, such as exercise, dance, or even spending time in nature, can be a productive way to release pent-up energy and emotions. 3. **Mindfulness and Grounding Techniques**: Practices like meditation, deep breathing exercises, or grounding techniques can help you reconnect with your feelings and bring some calmness to the chaos inside. 4. **Creative Expression**: Sometimes, engaging in art, music, or writing can provide an outlet for emotions that are hard to articulate. It might help you feel more connected to your feelings and express the "scream" in a different way. 5. **Professional Support**: If these feelings persist and are overwhelming, speaking to a mental health professional can be incredibly beneficial. They can provide support and tools to help navigate your emotions. 6. **Social Connection**: Spending time with supportive friends or loved ones can help alleviate feelings of isolation and provide an opportunity to share your feelings if you feel comfortable. Remember that it’s okay to feel the way you do, and seeking understanding and support is a positive step forward.

First of all, I am sorry that you have been missing out on your childhood. It may help you to know that many of us feel that we have missed out on our childhoods, as well, and that despite such deprivations, for many of us, our adult lives have been extraordinarily fulfilling due to our opening up to trusted adults. It sounds like a tough time and it's normal to feel down when your family is going through a divorce or other hardship. There's a difference between feelings like sadness, discouragement, grief, loneliness and depression, though. Sadness is sadness and sometimes we have to go through a grieving or other process, that is a normal reaction to events in our lives. Depression, on the other hand, is more about being stuck. Lulling yourself with self-care sounds like a healthy response and a way to give yourself support. So as to the uncomfortable but healthy part of your feelings, do the best you can to put names to it and share with a trusted other person. You will find comfort. The part of your situation that's depression -- feeling stuck, not able to get out of bad, concentrate, changes in sleeping and eating, loss of enjoyment in living, poor hygiene, feelings of hopelessness, that's different. First step, identify your own symptoms of depression. If you have any thoughts of hurting yourself, tell someone. If you're not sure, you can try 800-lifenet or other support line to get feedback. First aid for depression includes: daily care and feeding, good sleeping and eating, lots of exercise--even when you don't feel like it-- healthy socializing, and focusing on talking to yourself in a positive way. If you aren't able to move yourself out of your depression, work with a professional to make short-term goals and get some support. You may also talk to your doctor or psychiatrist about trying an anti-depressant to give you a little lift while you go through a rough patch.Best wishes,Karen

I couldn't help but notice that you did not specify your age, so I am unable to set the total chronological order and length that you have suffered in this way, but I want to start by commending you on seeking out additional coping techniques on your own. Unfortunately, it sounds like you were offered some that were more dangerous than helpful, but be proud that you were able to curb those before they caused too much harm. From what you have written, stress has always been a difficult thing for you to manage. Often, when I am working with those who offer the same concern, there is a degree of people pleasing that comes with that stress. When we are trying to make others happy, especially when we are unable to distinguish the proper "rules for success", it can make even the simplest of tasks overwhelming. Stress management is just that, management; of our own anxieties about the needs of others, about our skills and the ability to complete a task and having multiple requests at any given time. Each of these aspects requires a separate sets of "tools" to manage them accordingly. For example, assertiveness communication training could aid in communicating with your colleagues to manage their expectations of your deadlines and abilities, but it will not assist you with managing your own anxieties. Try to separate the different areas of the problem, in order to help yourself to find a solution and work on them in their own time. Perhaps keeping a journal will help you to better understand why you are so easily overwhelmed by stress and help you track some of your less-helpful responses to stress. For example, does a certain person's style of communication always make you feel undervalued and therefore push you to finish their requests first? Is there a certain time of the day where you start to fall off in productivity? Is that the time fo the day where you also tend to pile up your requirements?Try to ask yourself some of these harder questions and see where they lead you.

I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing this pain and struggle. It's understandable that the combination of bullying, academic pressure, and past experiences can lead to feelings of hopelessness and overwhelm. Acknowledging these challenges is the first step toward finding a way to cope and heal. Here are some suggestions that might help you as you navigate through these feelings: 1. **Seek Professional Help**: It can be incredibly beneficial to talk to a mental health professional. Therapists can provide support and tools to help you manage stress, cope with difficult emotions, and develop healthier thinking patterns. 2. **Explore Coping Mechanisms**: Finding appropriate coping strategies is essential. Instead of self-harm, consider healthier alternatives like journaling, physical activity, art, or mindfulness practices such as meditation or yoga. These can serve as outlets for stress and improve your overall well-being. 3. **Develop Problem-Solving Skills**: When faced with a problem, try breaking it down into smaller, manageable steps. This can help you feel less overwhelmed and more in control. Additionally, consider practicing positive self-talk to counter feelings of hopelessness. 4. **Build a Support Network**: Reach out to friends, family, or support groups where you can share your feelings and experiences. Having a support system can help alleviate some of the burdens you carry and provide perspective. 5. **Practice Self-Compassion**: Be gentle with yourself. It’s normal to struggle, and it’s okay to ask for help when you need it. Recognize your strengths and achievements, no matter how small they may seem. 6. **Establish a Routine**: Create a daily routine that includes self-care activities. Structure can provide stability, and incorporating mindfulness or relaxation techniques can help you manage stress more effectively. 7. **Set Realistic Goals**: Start with small, achievable goals to build your confidence over time. Celebrate your progress, and remember that setbacks are a normal part of the healing process. 8. **Limit Social Media**: Sometimes, social media can exacerbate feelings of inadequacy or stress. Consider reducing your time on these platforms to foster a healthier mindset. Remember that healing is a journey, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. You’re not alone in this, and there are people and resources available to help you through these challenging feelings.

It sounds like you have been struggling with this for quite some time, using many of the same coping techniques that feel tried and true to no avail. Often, we fall back on coping techniques that would be helpful in other problems (stress, social anxieties, etc.) for our depression, but the truth is that depression requires it's own little tool kit. Depression is all-encompassing, and, based on what you've written, the symptoms are already affecting work and your personal life in myriad ways. The best route forward would be to seek out counselling, admittedly, but if your insurance deductible is too high, that can be very expensive. I would recommend contacting your Employee Assistance Program (EAP) if offered by your employer. If not, you can look into community centres for counselling options, check if your doctor will give you a referral or your local religious organization. If, however, you are motivated to get your depression under control, there are some great workbooks out there that you can use on your own or with your therapist (as long as your therapist is trained in Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, or CBT), such as "Mind Over Mood".

Hello, and thank you for your question. This is a very serious time. I don't mean to frighten you, but you are right to be concerned. The time right after people leave the hospital after receiving psychiatric services is a time of high risk for suicide. It is very important, after hospitalization, to get follow-up care with a professional as soon as possible. If your husband has an established therapist, this is the time to call. It is also a good time to alert your support system of friends, family, clergy or others to let them know he is still struggling. This is good support for him AND you.It is important to think about means and opportunity to make another attempt. Means really do matter. So, if you have a firearm in the home, it is really important to remove it. You can't remove all things that a person may hurt themselves with, but some things are more lethal than others. Firearms are very lethal. I am not sure what means he used last time, but try to reduce the opportunity for him to access it again. This is where your support system can help out. People can take turns hanging out with him until you are sure the crisis is over.If you believe that an attempt is going to occur, talk to your husband about going back to the hospital. If he refuses, you will want to find out what your options are to have him go even if he doesn't want to. I know the thought of that really hurts, but it can save his life. Calling 9-1-1 is always a good option if you are not sure. Usually a suicide crisis, meaning they want to harm themselves right now, lasts a few minutes, hours or days. Sometimes when you get them through the crisis stage, they no longer want to commit suicide. But, as you are indicating, that feeling of wanting to commit suicide can come back again. So, it is always good to have a plan. If you want more information, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. They will always answer: 1-800-273-8255. They can help you create a specific safety plan. I do hope things work out alright. Be well. Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCC

It sounds like he’s going through a difficult emotional journey, experiencing a wide range of feelings after his hospital stay. You are describing some of the most common symptoms of depression: low self esteem, difficulty sleeping, changes in appetite, sad mood, feelings of hopeless and feelings of worthlessness. A full assessment/evaluation with a mental health professional is warranted to understand if indeed you meet criteria for a Major Depressive Disorder i.e.., are delressed. One thing I often tell patients is that "Do you think you are depressed?" People often answer yes or no, but many individuals respond with a question: How would I know? To that I often explain that if I stopped watching movies or better, stopped enjoying watching movies that would be a clear indication for me that I am delressed. It would be a sign that I have lost pleasure or interest in the activity that I typically enjoy most . I'll ask you to think of one activity which you really really enjoy. It could be anything from reading, to being with friends, to skiing to watching tv. I would like to now ask you if you have stopped enjoying that activity or can't find the motivation to engage in it? This is another symptom of depression: loss in pleasurable activities. The good news is that there are many effective, available treatment if you are indeed in a depression or simply, you want to modify/decrease your depressive symptoms i.e., you want to stop feeling so tired and so worthless. Treatment includes one or more of the following: psychotherapy, medication, exercise. Any one or combination of both of these can help to improve your mood. The even better news is that feeling that you are doing something wrong can diminish with appropriate treatment over time. I hope you find this information helpful. The most important next step is to get evaluated by a mental health professional typically a psychologist or psychiatrist, and for both you and the professional to better understand your symptoms and your mood in the context of what is going on in your life.

Hi Georgia, There's a really good lesson here. People tell us things, and we tend to think that's the truth...but it's not! For starters, commend yourself for being committed to working. You have no idea what is going to happen in the next second, so focusing on thinking you will never have a good career or amount to anything financially is creating a fictitious story. Remind yourself of that every time the thought pops up. The false belief that nothing good will happen is sucking out energy you can use on pursuing your career dreams. Next, do you know what you need to do to become an electrician or heavy machinery operator? If not, find out. Then, set up a realistic schedule for yourself to accomplish the steps. As you accomplish each step, see your progress. Notice that you are moving closer to your goal. Every day remind yourself why you are pursuing this career. In fact, write it down and tape it on your bathroom mirror. When you start to feel discouraged, remember your goal and remind yourself that you have no idea if you'll make it or not but you are going to give it everything you have to find out. Anything worth pursuing is going to take a lot of persistence and hard work. Stay with it! You and your family are worth it!

It's great to hear that you have goals and are thinking about the future for yourself and your family. Feeling stuck or unsure about how to move toward your ambitions is a common challenge, but taking small, actionable steps can help you build momentum. Here are some suggestions to help you get started: ### 1. **Identify Your Goals Clearly** - Break down your broader goals (becoming an electrician, operating heavy machinery) into smaller, specific steps. For example: - Research training programs for electricians or heavy machinery operators. - Look into local community colleges or trade schools that offer related courses. ### 2. **Make a Plan** - Create a timeline for achieving your goals. Set short-term and long-term goals to make the process manageable. For example: - Short-term: Enroll in a program within the next three months. - Long-term: Complete your training and obtain a license within the next one to two years. ### 3. **Seek Support** - Talk to your fiancée about your aspirations, and involve her in the planning process. Supporting each other in pursuing your goals can strengthen your partnership. - Connect with mentors in the fields you're interested in. They can provide valuable advice and encouragement. ### 4. **Take Action** - Start small; even minor steps can lead to significant progress. This might be as simple as filling out an application or having a conversation with someone in the field. - Consider attending workshops or informational sessions related to your interests. ### 5. **Build Skills and Experience** - Look for part-time jobs, internships, or volunteer positions in your chosen field to gain experience. - Online resources, videos, and tutorials can also help you learn skills relevant to your goals. ### 6. **Stay Motivated** - Remind yourself of why you want to achieve these goals. Having a clear vision of a better life for your family can help you stay focused. - Celebrate small achievements along the way to keep your spirits high. ### 7. **Consider Financial Planning** - Look into financial aid, grants, or scholarships for training programs if cost is a concern. - Create a budget that allows you to set aside money for training or education. ### 8. **Stay Flexible** - Life can be unpredictable, so remain open to adjusting your plans as needed. Focus on what you can control and stay resilient in the face of challenges. Remember, progress often comes in small steps, and it's okay to take your time. Your determination to create a better life for your family is a powerful motivator, and with a clear plan and consistent effort, you can achieve your goals. Good luck!

Wow that is tough. There is nothing worse than fearing abandonment when you are already struggling with depression. It sounds like you are still wanting to work through whatever challenges you and your husband are having but your husband may not be on the same page. I would encourage you and your husband to seek professional support if you haven't already. While depression can put real strains on a relationship, relationship problems can lead to or contribute to depression and there may be some real benefits to both of you in doing some couple therapy. With that being said - if your husband is not willing to do therapy or is clear that he wants the relationship to end, then I can't see what choice you have but to "respect his decision" as you mentioned. This doesn't mean that you have to feel okay with the decision - as I'm sure you wouldn't - but ultimately loving one another and staying in committed relationships is a choice that we each have to make. If he is wanting to leave - this could make things a lot tougher for you. I would encourage you to seek professional support for yourself and reach out to lots of friends and family. You do not need to face depression alone - nor should you have to. We all need support at tough times like these.

Hello, and thank you for your question. First, I want to tell you how sorry I am for the experience you had with your parents. That is a grief and trauma that is certainly hard to imagine. Trauma and grief can affect us in many ways, and certainly deeply personal things like our sex lives. It may be difficult for others to make the connection, but it is there. So, for example, if stress and trauma make you feel like you are not interested in sex, a partner may take it as a personal rejection rather than response to stress, trauma or grief. If your husband will agree to it, couple's counseling may be your best bet. A counselor can help you with your communication and may be able to provide some education to your husband about trauma and how it can have an impact on intimacy. If he doesn't agree to go, it may be worth it to go on your own. You still have a lot you are dealing with yourself. And sometimes our personally therapy can influence others, so it may be a good idea. It is important to remember that even though you are married you have the right to make decisions about your body, and that includes when you want to have sex with it. I hope this is helpful, and some of my colleagues may have ideas, also. Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

I’m deeply sorry to hear about your loss and the pain you’re experiencing. What you’ve gone through is unimaginable, and it’s completely understandable that it has had a profound effect on your mental health and your relationship. Sexual intimacy can be complicated, especially when dealing with trauma and mental health struggles. It’s important to give yourself compassion and understand that healing takes time. Here are a few steps you might consider to help navigate this challenging situation: 1. **Seek Professional Support:** A therapist who specializes in grief and trauma can provide you with coping strategies and a safe space to express your feelings. They can help you process your loss and the emotions surrounding it. 2. **Communication with Your Husband:** Try to have an open conversation with your husband about your feelings. Expressing your struggles and the impact of your loss on your intimacy can help him understand your perspective better. It might help to emphasize that it’s not about him or your feelings towards him, but rather your own personal healing journey. 3. **Establish Boundaries:** It’s okay to set boundaries around physical intimacy if you’re not feeling ready. Talk about what you’re comfortable with, which may include non-sexual forms of closeness and affection, while you work through your feelings. 4. **Educate Him:** Sometimes partners may not understand the complexities of mental health. Sharing resources or articles on how trauma and depression can affect intimacy might provide him with insights. 5. **Take Your Time:** Healing is not linear, and each person's journey is unique. Allow yourself to heal at your own pace without pressure to resume intimacy before you’re ready. 6. **Support Groups:** Connecting with others who have experienced similar losses can provide a sense of community and understanding, which can be healing. Please remember that you are not alone, and reaching out for help from professionals or support networks can be a vital step in your healing journey.

Seeking professional help does not mean that you will necessarily be admitted into an inpatient setting - though to be honest, that can become an option if you feel unsafe or if you are unable to plan for safety. However, many clients who struggle with self-harm can find help in outpatient settings - particularly those which offer a treatment called Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT). Looking for a DBT professional or group therapy setting may be particularly helpful, but a skilled professional can help you to figure out how to identify other options even when you are experiencing overwhelming emotions. Without knowing your location, I also recommend searching to find your local helpline or suicide prevention hotline. The volunteers on the other end of the line can be very helpful even if your intention is not suicide and they are likely also to be able to connect you with resources in your area. Calling into the helpline may also be a first step alternative to self-harming when you're feeling overwhelmed.

Everyone has some level of anxiety - it's what helps us respond to stressors in our lives and clues us into the fact that we need to respond to something going on. However, if you're feeling overwhelmed by racing thoughts, feeling like you spend a lot of energy worrying about something specific or even pretty much anything at all, and you're starting to find that it's getting in your way when it comes to living your life the way you want, then I'd suggest seeing a counselor or therapist for an assessment for anxiety. Your other concerns, though, seem pretty "normal" for someone who is in a relationship with a partner who has children. As a married stepmother, I've been there, and as a therapist, I can tell you that the boundaries and communication skills you have in your relationships need to be healthy for you to feel healthy. Finding some support from a group of others whose partners have children might be really helpful - being able to hear from others that you aren't alone in feeling like this can really lighten the load, and they might have some good ideas for handling certain situations. Another option is to find a counselor or therapist who has experience working with step/blended family dynamics - because even if you're not officially married, those dynamics come into play whenever there are kids from another relationship involved. You may even consider couples counseling so that both of you can learn to talk about your relationship needs and concerns in a way that will encourage connection and strengthen your sense of partnership.

It's really important to talk to someone about what you’re feeling and experiencing, especially given the symptoms you’ve described. Here are some steps you can take to communicate your situation and ask for the help you need: 1. **Choose the Right Time and Place**: Find a quiet place where you can talk without distractions. If you’re seeing a mental health professional, schedule a specific time to meet. 2. **Be Honest and Direct**: When you talk to your therapist or doctor, be open about what you’re experiencing. You might start by saying something like, "I’ve been feeling really overwhelmed lately and I think I might be dealing with depression and anxiety." 3. **Describe Your Symptoms**: Mention the voices you’re hearing, your difficulties with sleep, and any thoughts of self-harm or past suicidal feelings. Providing specific examples can help them understand what you're going through. 4. **Discuss Your History**: Let them know about your previous diagnoses (ADD and OCD) because this information is important for understanding your overall mental health. 5. **Express Your Needs**: Clearly say that you’re seeking therapy and support. You can say something like, "I believe I need therapy to help me cope with these feelings and thoughts." 6. **Ask Questions**: If you’re unsure about what to expect from therapy or your treatment options, don’t hesitate to ask. You might want to ask how often you would meet or what kind of therapy they recommend. 7. **Be Patient with Yourself**: This conversation might feel overwhelming, but it’s a crucial step toward getting the support you need. It’s normal to feel nervous, but remember that seeking help is a sign of strength. If you don’t feel comfortable talking to someone in person yet, consider writing down your feelings in a letter or a journal. You can bring that with you to your appointment or send it to your provider if that feels easier. Taking the first step to ask for help can be daunting, but it’s a vital part of taking care of your mental health. You deserve support and care.

Being tired can really affect almost everyone's ability to work through things that make them sad, confused, or angry, among other emotions. If you're having difficulty sleeping, try to get into a habit of going to bed and waking up close to the same time every day. Also consider only using the bed for sleeping so your brain knows that it's time to sleep when you are in bed. If you are not sleeping while you are in bed, consider getting up and reading a book or doing something to make you tired before going back to bed. Hopefully you'll be able to establish a pattern.Sometimes sadness and other emotions make sleeping very difficult as well. Try keeping track of your moods to see what is leading up to the changes.If you're still struggling, consider talking with a therapist about the specifics and/or maybe talking with your primary care physician. There are natural sleep remedies that he or she may recommend for you.

It sounds like you're dealing with a challenging habit or behavior that you're finding hard to manage. It's not uncommon to feel trapped in an addiction-like cycle, where the desire becomes stronger the more you try to resist it. Finding effective coping strategies can be tough, especially when typical suggestions like drawing don’t seem to help. Consider exploring a few different approaches: 1. **Identify Triggers**: Reflect on what situations, emotions, or environments lead you to engage in this behavior. Understanding the triggers can help you develop strategies to avoid or cope with them. 2. **Substitution**: If drawing isn't working, try other activities that might engage your mind and body, like physical exercise, writing, or even starting a new hobby that excites you. 3. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you become more aware of your thoughts and feelings without necessarily acting on them. Apps like Headspace or Calm can guide you. 4. **Support from Others**: Talk to a friend, family member, or a mental health professional who can help provide support or accountability. Sometimes just sharing what you’re going through can be a relief. 5. **Set Small Goals**: Instead of trying to stop entirely, set smaller, manageable goals. Celebrate progress, no matter how small. 6. **Professional Help**: If your habit is significantly impacting your life, it might be beneficial to consult with a therapist or counselor who can provide tailored strategies and support. Remember, it's okay to seek help, and taking small steps can lead to meaningful change over time.

It's important to acknowledge what you're feeling and thinking, as it can be a crucial step in understanding your mental health. It’s common for people to feel apathetic, unmotivated, or disconnected from their interests or responsibilities, even if they can still engage socially and make jokes. Here are a few things to consider: 1. **Reflect on Your Feelings**: Try to identify specific thoughts or patterns you've noticed. Feelings of emptiness or questioning the purpose of life can be signs of depression, even if you're not feeling overtly sad. 2. **Physical and Mental Well-Being**: Consider factors like sleep, nutrition, and physical activity. Sometimes fatigue or burnout can mimic or contribute to depressive symptoms. 3. **Changes in Behavior**: Have you noticed significant changes in your appetite, sleep patterns, or motivation? These can be indicators of a shift in your mental health. 4. **Seek Support**: Speaking with a mental health professional can provide clarity and guidance. They can help you navigate your feelings and decide on the best course of action. 5. **Talk to Trusted Friends or Family**: Sometimes sharing how you feel with someone close can provide perspective and support. Remember, reaching out for help is a sign of strength, and it’s okay to seek assistance if you’re feeling uncertain about your mental health. You deserve support and care.

Philadelphia, there is help out there. For your daughter's sake, start somewhere. Feelings are only that; your worst fears about who you are are only based on a few moments that haven't gone well. Someone who was around you when you were that outgoing person? Someone who's been watching your life from the start? God? Write that best story. This could be as simple as tidying a space or cooking a meal. 5. **Mindfulness and Relaxation**: Techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or yoga can help ground you and reduce feelings of anxiety and frustration. 6. **Self-compassion**: Remind yourself that it’s okay to feel overwhelmed. Be kind to yourself during this time. 7. **Explore Support Groups**: Sometimes, connecting with others who are going through similar experiences can be incredibly validating and encouraging. Remember, it’s a process to feel better, and it’s okay to take it one step at a time. Your feelings are valid, and seeking help when you need it is a strong and positive step forward.

It sounds like you are feeling pretty overwhelmed and stuck between wanting to improve your work situation and worrying that you won't be able to. It is possible that the paralysis, uncertainty, and self-doubt that you describe are contributing to your difficulty in getting and maintaining a satisfying job as employers generally like to see that a potential employee is confident and can think on his or her feet. With a competent therapist, you may be able to get more understanding of the roots of these feelings and learn how to move forward in your search for a better work life in a way that leaves you feeling confident and capable.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed, especially when past experiences weigh heavily on your mind. Here are some strategies that might help you cope with your feelings and improve your situation: 1. **Reflect on Past Experiences**: While it can be painful, try to analyze what went wrong in your previous roles. Understanding specific challenges you faced might help you identify areas for improvement without internalizing it as a reflection of your worth. 2. **Focus on Your Strengths**: Make a list of your skills and accomplishments, both professional and personal. This can help remind you of your value and capabilities, and you can refer back to this list during interviews to boost your confidence. 3. **Seek Support**: It might be beneficial to talk to a therapist or counselor. They can provide support and strategies to cope with depression and anxiety, particularly around work situations like interviews. 4. **Practice Interviewing**: Role-playing interviews with a friend or family member can help desensitize you to the experience and improve your confidence. Prepare responses to common questions and practice speaking about your experiences candidly. 5. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Incorporate relaxation exercises, such as deep breathing, meditation, or yoga, to help manage anxiety. These can be effective in reducing feelings of paralysis during interview situations. 6. **Gradual Exposure**: If possible, start applying for positions that feel a little less intimidating. This could be more casual roles, volunteer opportunities, or internships to build experience and confidence before tackling larger career moves. 7. **Set Realistic Goals**: Break your job search into manageable tasks. Instead of focusing on getting hired, aim to submit a certain number of applications each week or practice interviewing a few times. 8. **Consider Professional Help**: If your depression is worsening, please reach out to a mental health professional. They can help you develop coping strategies and address feelings of hopelessness. 9. **Network and Seek Mentorship**: Connect with mentors, supportive colleagues, or even friends who can offer advice, referrals, or simply moral support. Networking often leads to opportunities that aren't always visible through traditional job postings. 10. **Be Kind to Yourself**: Acknowledge that everyone faces setbacks in their careers. Try to treat yourself with compassion and understand that your worth isn’t defined by a job or others’ perceptions of you. Remember, you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people eventually find a path that suits them, and with support and self-compassion, you're taking steps toward a brighter future.

It seems like you may be experiencing depression symptoms, they could be the triggered by unexpected life changes, or building up throughout time.The important part is that you have identified them and wanting to change them. The first step is to establish a self-care routine that will help you to feel centered and motivated: go for walks, or make any physical activity that you enjoy ( be kind to yourself, anything helps at this point), eat balanced, add whole grains and fibers to your diet, make a point to rest at night and avoid naps, practice a hobby that you love, or look for a new one that you are curious about. You mentioned that you feel unsettled in your soul: explore your spirituality, meditate about what makes your soul at peace, and find ways to practice that or surround yourself by those activities.If you find it difficult to begin, talk to your therapist to identify roadblocks and ways to find motivation. Suicidal and homicidal thoughts are common but serious depression symptoms, discuss them with your therapist, contact your doctor or psychiatrist, and call 9-1-1 if its and emergency.Once you feel stable, you can focus on exploring the source of the problem and see if you need to make changes or learn coping skills that will help you manage it. El primer paso sería trabajar en restablecer una rutina de cuidado personal que te ayude a sentirte emocionalmente estable y motivado: Sal a caminar o hacer alguna actividad física(ten compasión contigo mismo, cualquier cosa funciona para comenzar), comienza a comer balanceado, especialmente granos y fibras integrales, , procura descansar en las noches y evita las siestas, y practica algún tipo de actividad que hayas disfrutado en el pasado o que te de curiosidad. I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to acknowledge how you're feeling and to know that you're not alone in experiencing such thoughts. Many people go through times when they feel lost or disconnected from themselves and others. It might help to take a step back and reflect on the things that have caused these feelings. Sometimes, journaling about your thoughts or talking to someone you trust can offer clarity. It’s also worth considering if there are specific situations or struggles that are weighing heavily on you. Remember that it's okay to reach out for support, whether that’s from friends, family, or a mental health professional. They can provide a different perspective and help you work through your feelings. Lastly, try to be gentle with yourself. Everyone has ups and downs, and it’s okay to seek help when you’re feeling down. You deserve kindness and care, especially from yourself.

You are not alone, many people fear opening up to family members about the topic of depression or mental illness. There are many different reason why some may fear telling their parents. The most common thoughts I hear in my office are: " My parents won't understand me", I may cause more problems to the family", "I am worried that something bad may happen if I tell them". If possible express your current concerns and worries to your parents. You can start the conversation with your parents by saying "I have not been feeling like myself lately, and I may want to see a counselor". I think you are doing the right thing by going on this website and asking for help. Just a helpful tip: positive self-talk can be beneficial before having difficult conversations with others. For example, tell yourself something positive before talking to your parents such as "I feel confident in myself, and I am doing this to overcome my fear of talking to my parents" can help to decrease the anxiety you are feeling leading up to the conversation. I would recommend if you are feeling depressed or down it would be beneficial to seek counseling to understand your current thoughts and behaviors. Best of luck and hope you decide to start counseling.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It can be tough to navigate feelings of uncertainty and sadness, especially when it comes to discussing them with family. Here are some steps you might consider taking: 1. **Reflect on Your Feelings**: Take some time to think about what you're experiencing. Sometimes writing in a journal can help clarify your thoughts and feelings. 2. **Identify Specific Concerns**: Try to pinpoint specific feelings or situations that seem to contribute to your sadness or confusion. This can help make the conversation more focused. 3. **Choose the Right Time and Place**: When you're ready to talk to your parents, find a time when they’re not busy or stressed. A calm environment can make it easier to have an open conversation. 4. **Start Small**: You can start the conversation by expressing that you've been feeling off or not quite yourself lately. There’s no need to label it as depression right away; just sharing that you’re struggling can be a helpful step. 5. **Be Honest**: If you feel comfortable, share specific feelings or experiences. Let them know that you’re seeking understanding and support. 6. **Ask for Help**: Your parents may have ideas about how to help, whether that’s talking to a professional or finding resources together. 7. **Consider Professional Support**: If you think you might be dealing with depression, it may be helpful to talk to someone trained to help, like a therapist or counselor. Remember, it's okay to seek help, and you deserve support during tough times.

It sounds like you are feeling pretty stuck, lonely, and hopeless; like you have a desire to be more connected to people and to find purpose in life, but are not sure what to do. I am glad to hear that you have at least one friend and I think it is great that you are reaching out for more connection. If you can, working with a therapist who is competent in treating depression may be a huge benefit to you and help you to regain a sense of meaning, motivation, and connection. Additionally, anything you can do to give yourself a little break from the feeling of pointlessness and any ruminating thoughts you may be having may be of help. I know it may sound pointless in the moment, and you may feel a great deal of inertia in doing so, but you may find that if you force yourself to do something small that is pleasurable, like taking a walk for example, there's a good chance you will be glad that you did so after the fact. Thank you for reaching out.

It sounds like you're going through a tough time, feeling isolated and disconnected. It’s completely valid to feel this way, and recognizing how you feel is the first step toward making a change. Here are a few suggestions that might help you start feeling more connected and fulfilled: 1. **Reach Out**: Try reaching out to your one friend and suggest doing something together, maybe go for a walk, grab a coffee, or try a new hobby together. Face-to-face interactions can be really uplifting. 2. **Explore New Activities**: Look for local clubs, classes, or community events that interest you. This can be a great way to meet new people and engage in something you enjoy. 3. **Volunteer**: Consider getting involved in a local charity or community service. It’s a wonderful way to meet people, do something meaningful, and get out of the house. 4. **Talk to Your Family**: It might feel a bit uncomfortable, but if you feel safe doing so, try to have a conversation with your family about how you’re feeling. They may not realize how distant things feel for you. 5. **Limit Phone Time**: Try setting specific times for phone use and dedicate the rest of your time to activities that don’t involve screens; this can help reduce feelings of isolation. 6. **Consider Professional Help**: If you’re feeling persistently low or overwhelmed, talking to a therapist or counselor could provide you with support and new strategies for dealing with these feelings. 7. **Personal Goals**: Set small, achievable goals for yourself, whether it’s reading a book, starting a fitness routine, or learning a new skill. This can help create a sense of purpose. 8. **Mindfulness and Self-Care**: Explore mindfulness practices like meditation or journaling, which can help you process your feelings and reduce feelings of loneliness. Small steps can lead to big changes over time. You don’t have to make all these changes at once—pick one or two things to try out first and see how you feel. Remember, it’s okay to take your time in finding what works for you.

Anxiety and Depression are challenging experiences to live with and to manage on a daily basis. I would say that both are challenges to overcome but solutions to living healthy and well exist. Step 1: Talk about it. With friends, family, partners, counselors, and other trusted people in your life. Step 2: Create a plan with a counselor to learn new skills that help you recognize and manage your symptoms. Step 3: Don't give up. Working on yourself can be difficult and hard at the beginning. Stick with it and you will be able to find exercises, tools, and resources that help you live well.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you, like a mental health professional. You don't have to go through this alone; there are people who care and can offer support. If you're feeling overwhelmed, including just getting out of bed or facing daily tasks, these feelings are valid, and reaching out for help is a brave step. Here are a few suggestions that might help you cope in the meantime: 1. **Reach out for support**: Talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling. Sometimes just sharing your thoughts can lighten the load. 2. **Small steps**: Set very small goals for each day. This could be as simple as sitting up in bed, drinking a glass of water, or taking a shower. Celebrate these small victories. 3. **Routine**: If possible, try to establish a simple daily routine. This can help create a sense of structure and normalcy. 4. **Physical activity**: Even a short walk or gentle stretching can help elevate your mood. Physical activity releases endorphins, which can help combat feelings of depression. 5. **Mindfulness and breathing**: Techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga can help ease anxiety and ground you in the moment. 6. **Limit social media and news**: Sometimes, what we consume can influence our mood. Taking a break from these can be beneficial. 7. **Professional help**: Therapists or counselors can provide coping strategies and support tailored to your needs. Please remember that it's okay to ask for help, and there are people who want to support you in this tough time.

It sounds like you're experiencing a complex mix of emotions and thoughts. Sleep can be a way to escape or recharge, while music often serves as a powerful emotional outlet or trigger. Crying regularly could indicate that you’re processing feelings that might not be fully acknowledged, and the metaphor of your mind being a maze suggests feelings of confusion or being overwhelmed. Experiencing "fake mirrored" emotions might imply that you sometimes struggle to connect with your true feelings or that your emotions are influenced by external factors—like the moods of others or societal expectations. It could be helpful to explore these thoughts further, possibly through journaling, creative expression, or talking with someone who can provide support, like a therapist. Understanding your emotions can be a journey, and it's okay to take your time with it. If you're comfortable, what do you think is at the root of these feelings?

First, let me say that you are a survivor and a warrior. Managing 1 child by yourself is difficult, but twins is a whole different ballgame. Anxiety can affect us at any time anywhere. This is the challenge, especially when we have so many things to manage each day. There are several methods and practices that help manage and even reduce symptoms of anxiety. It will depend on what works best for you. Talk with friends, a counselor, or a loved one who can offer you support and feedback as you navigate this process of learning what works for you. When all else fails; make sure you are in a safe place, pause for a deep, cleansing breath in, a long exhale out, and ask yourself, "What do I want in this moment?" Now you can begin again.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a challenging time. It sounds like you’ve faced a lot of difficult situations, from the loss of a loved one to a turbulent relationship and the responsibilities of raising twin toddlers. They can provide a safe space to process your feelings and help you cope with your grief and stress. 3. **Self-Care**: It’s important to find moments for yourself, even if it's just a few minutes a day. Whether it's reading a book, taking a walk, or enjoying a cup of tea, self-care can help rejuvenate you. 4. **Create a Routine**: Establishing a daily routine can bring some stability to your life and help manage the demands of parenting toddlers. 5. **Prioritize Communication**: If you’re in contact with your ex, try to focus on co-parenting effectively. Clear communication can help reduce conflicts and ease some of the difficulties you’ve experienced. 6. **Explore Online Communities**: If you don’t have friends nearby, there are many online forums and groups where you can share your experiences and connect with others going through similar situations. 7. **One Step at a Time**: It's okay to take things one day at a time. This may be happening because you and the others are not connected to each other on a level which reaches your emotions.Loneliness may show the absence of feeling a variety of emotions when you are among others.How many friends you have doesn't affect whether you and someone else feel emotionally engaged with one another.Consider if you feel like concentrating your friendship on more intensively sharing your feelings with a few of your friends.This may lead to fewer friends who are also more meaningful to you and your feeling a decrease of loneliness.

It's not uncommon to feel lonely even when surrounded by friends and family. Loneliness can stem from a variety of factors, such as: 1. **Lack of Deeper Connections**: Sometimes, we may have a lot of acquaintances but fewer people we can truly connect with on a deeper emotional level. It might help to identify a few friends or family members with whom you could share your feelings more openly. 2. **Feeling Misunderstood**: If you feel that others don’t understand you or where you’re coming from, it can lead to feelings of isolation. Finding people with similar interests or experiences can create a sense of belonging. 3. **Changes in Life Circumstances**: Life changes, such as moving to a new place, changing jobs, or going through a significant life event, can affect feelings of loneliness. Adjusting to these changes takes time. 4. **Mental Health**: Sometimes loneliness can be associated with mental health issues such as depression or anxiety. If you think this may be the case, seeking support from a mental health professional can be beneficial. 5. **Quality vs. Quantity**: It’s important to focus on the quality of relationships rather than the quantity. Meaningful interactions, even if they are fewer, can have a greater impact on your feeling of connectedness. 6. **Engagement and Purpose**: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and purpose can also help combat feelings of loneliness. Volunteering, joining clubs, or participating in events can create opportunities to connect with others. 7. **Self-Reflection**: Sometimes, asking yourself what you truly want from your relationships and reflecting on your feelings can provide clarity. Journaling your thoughts may also be a helpful way to process your feelings. Consider reaching out to someone you trust to talk about how you’re feeling. You might find that they have similar experiences, and sharing can create a stronger bond.

One of the first steps is to manage anxiety and depression symptoms are to establish a good self-care routine. Start with the most basic things: Eating balanced meals, sleeping at from 6-8 hours and exercise at least 30 minutes a day. These will help you to regulate the chemical imbalance that affects your mood, plus exercising gives you time to vent and be distracted from your thoughts. Once basic self-care is established, I suggest that is a good time to start exploring the source of these feelings, and address them trough therapy. If you have difficulty initiating self-care routine talk to your therapist about what motivates you and pushes you to do things, you might find the key during the process. You could also contact your physician or a psychiatrist to discuss medication options if it’s too challenging to begin basic self-care.¿Cómo puedo controlar mi ansiedad?Uno de los primeros pasos para manejar la ansiedad y la depresión es establecer una buena rutina de cuidado personal. Comienza con las cosas más básicas: Comer comidas balanceadas, dormir de 6-8 horas en la noche, y ejercitarte por lo menos 30 minutos al día. Esto te ayudara a regular el desbalance químico que afecta tu estado de ánimo, además de que te da tiempo para desahogarte y distraerte. Ya que la rutina de cuidado eta establecida, es un buen momento para comenzar a explorar la fuente de tus sentimientos negativos, y explóralos a través de terapia. Si se dificulta comenzar a crear una rutina puedes consultar con tu terapista para identificar motivaciones que te impulsen a comenzar. También puedes contactar a tu medico primario o psiquiatra para discutir medicamentos que te pueden ayudar a manejar estos síntomas e iniciar cuidado básico.

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's tough to deal with anxiety, especially when it's a new experience. Many people find that anxiety can lead to feelings of sadness or depression, so you're not alone in that. Here are a few steps you might consider taking to help manage your anxiety and improve your mood: 1. **Talk About It**: Sharing your feelings with someone you trust, such as a friend, family member, or therapist, can be really helpful. Sometimes just expressing what you're going through can provide some relief. 2. **Professional Help**: If your anxiety and depression persist, a mental health professional can offer support tailored to your situation. Therapy, such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), can be particularly effective for anxiety and depression. 3. **Relaxation Techniques**: Mindfulness, meditation, and deep-breathing exercises can help reduce feelings of anxiety. Regular practice can also improve your overall mood. 4. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise is a powerful tool for managing anxiety and depression. It can help reduce stress and boost your mood. 5. **Establish a Routine**: Having a daily structure can provide a sense of normalcy and control, which can be comforting. Try to incorporate activities that you enjoy. 6. **Limit Stressors**: If you’re aware of specific triggers for your anxiety, try to limit exposure to those stressors where possible. 7. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Make sure you’re eating well and getting enough sleep. These factors can have a significant impact on how you feel emotionally. 8. **Limit Stimulants**: Caffeine and nicotine can increase feelings of anxiety, so you might want to cut back. 9. **Self-Compassion**: Be gentle with yourself. It’s okay to feel this way, and acknowledging your feelings can be the first step toward working through them. It’s important to know that you’re not alone and that help is available. Taking even small steps can make a big difference over time.

Hello, and thank you for your question. It certainly sounds like you don't like how things are going. Here are a few thoughts and ideas:1. If you haven't seen a primary care provider in a while, you may want to. There are health conditions that can affect your mood and energy levels, even at your age. It doesn't hurt to get checked out. If they find the cause, they may be able to treat it and improve the symptoms. In addition, most primary care providers are trained to be able to manage medication for patients who have mild, moderate, and sometimes severe depression. So, don't be surprised if your primary care doctor offers to put you on an anti-depressant if they diagnose you with depression. Medication is not the only way to treat depression, but sometimes it is necessary depending on different factors.2. You may want to consider counseling, since it is another effective way to treat depression. A counselor will help you explore the factors that may be leading to depressive symptoms in the first place. This could include thoughts, behaviors, beliefs, life experiences, and other things. 3. Finally, to answer your question about whether these feelings are "normal." These symptoms could be the sign of an underlying general health or mental health condition. It is important to remember that even if these symptoms are "abnormal" it doesn't mean that YOU are. Millions of people struggle with depression. So remember, the symptoms are the problem, not YOU. Hope this helps. Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It can be really tough to deal with feelings of exhaustion, annoyance, and a lack of interest in things. While it's not uncommon to go through periods of feeling down or disconnected, experiencing persistent feelings of fatigue, irritation, and lack of motivation can be signs of underlying issues such as depression or anxiety. Here are a few things you might consider: 1. **Professional Help**: Talking to a mental health professional can be very helpful. They can provide support, strategies for coping, and possibly help you explore any underlying issues. 2. **Physical Health**: Sometimes physical health issues can contribute to feelings of fatigue and irritability. Consider checking in with a healthcare provider to rule out any medical conditions that might be affecting your energy levels. 3. **Routine**: Establishing a daily routine can provide structure and help create a sense of normalcy. It can include simple activities like going for a walk, reading, or engaging in light stretching. 4. **Small Steps**: If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the idea of finding hobbies or interests, start small. Try setting aside a few minutes each day to explore different activities without pressure. This could be as simple as listening to music, drawing, or watching a new show. 5. **Social Connections**: While it can be challenging, try to reach out to others, whether it's family members, acquaintances, or online groups. Sometimes connecting with others can help alleviate feelings of isolation. 6. **Mindfulness and Relaxation**: Practices such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga can help you feel more centered and reduce feelings of anxiety. 7. **Limit Stimuli**: If you're easily annoyed, consider reducing exposure to social media, news, or other stressors that may contribute to your feelings. It's important to be patient with yourself as you work through these feelings. You're not alone, and taking small steps can lead to significant changes over time. If things feel too heavy to cope with on your own, please reach out for help.

It has been said that depression is often the result of a blocked goal. Often people struggle with both anxiety and depression but have difficulty determining which is the most important issue. For some, depression is the result of frequently blocked goals and when their predominant issues are evaluated, they discover that they are anxious (worried) about a lot of areas in their life but seem to find no relief. When there is no relief and there have been numerous attempts (either in their mind or in practical application) to resolve the anxiety, depression is often the result. In this type of case, depression is not the main or underlying issue. The anxiety is the underlying issue. Having "a lot on my mind" sounds like anxiety. Unresolved anxiety can lead to feelings of depression which are often associated with "emptiness." In the question above, I would want to evaluate all of the issues surrounding having "a lot on my mind" and determine where these might be coming from. Has there been ongoing rejection from peers? From family? If so, why does this seem to be happening? Isolation is often a protective measure that one implements to avoid further pain. Where does that need to protect originate? Are there unmet needs from childhood? Are there traumatic life events that have created a need to self-protect as a defense mechanism? We can feel "alone" even when in a crow of people or at a party. This has nothing, in this case, to do with being around people. It has more to do with how we view ourselves. If there is a prevailing message or script that has been internalized that says, "You are worth nothing" or "You don't deserve the company of others" then being around people will not alleviate the problem but only exacerbate it. I would want to evaluate how one feels about themselves and what negative messages one has received and has repeated to oneself over time. The Developmental Needs Meeting Strategy is a therapy aimed at addressing unmet childhood needs. If there is specific trauma that is associated with socializing with people, then EMDR can be very helpful in desensitizing and reprocessing the trauma. Looking at whether this individual's issue with emptiness is straight depression or whether it is depression as a result of unresolved anxiety is key to determining a treatment strategy.

Feeling alone, especially when you prefer to isolate yourself, can be quite common and may stem from various factors. Here are a few possibilities to consider: 1. **Overwhelm**: If you have a lot on your mind, it can feel exhausting to interact with others. Taking time for yourself can sometimes seem like the best way to recharge. 2. **Social Fatigue**: Interacting with others, even people you care about, can be draining. If you've been socializing a lot or dealing with stress, it's natural to yearn for solitude. 3. **Mood and Emotions**: Feelings of loneliness can sometimes be linked to mood fluctuations or emotional challenges. If you’re feeling down or anxious, it might be hard to connect with others. 4. **Lack of Connection**: Sometimes, feeling alone can stem from a lack of meaningful connections. You might be physically surrounded by people but still feel emotionally distant from them. 5. **Personal Reflection**: Isolation can also provide an opportunity for introspection. You may be processing thoughts or emotions that require solitude to understand. 6. **Changes in Circumstances**: Life events such as moving, changing jobs, or personal losses can disrupt social ties and contribute to feelings of loneliness. If these feelings persist, it might help to reach out to someone you trust or consider speaking with a professional who can assist you in exploring these emotions. Taking small steps to connect with others, even in low-pressure situations, can also be beneficial. Remember, it’s okay to feel this way, and seeking help is a strong and positive step.

If the symptoms are to the extent that they are affecting your ability to function, you may want to consider seeking treatment. PTSD, anxiety, and depression all typically respond well to treatment if provided by a trained clinician. Common types of treatment for PTSD that you may want to look into include Cognitive Processing Therapy or EMDR. The nice things about Cognitive Processing Therapy is that it is time limited and only lasts 17 sessions typically.

I understand that at times it’s difficult to share with our parents what we have been trough, due to fear of judgment or punishment; but I have noticed that keeping our experiences secret, intensifies them. And Post Traumatic Stress Disorder can haunt us for a long time if we do not learn to process the memories that cause those symptoms. If you have been victim of a traumatic event that you are not prepared to share with your parents, it’s important that you seek help with a counselor, therapist or psychologist. Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a great technique to cope with physical symptoms, you could also use Narrative therapy, Creative Therapy or Journaling as a way to express memories and process them with your therapist. A psychiatrist can also prescribe medication to manage the symptoms, but is very important that you address the trauma so you can heal and go back to live your life. Many organizations like the United Way (2-1-1 in many states) offer resources and referrals to put you in touch with mental health providers, you could also talk to your school counselor, doctor or church to find referral that could help. Tip: You don’t have to tell you story to each person you ask for help, you can just start by asking for a counselor referral. ¿Cómo puedo superar el Desorden de Estrés Post Traumático sin que mis padres se enteren?Comprendo que muchas veces puede ser difícil compartir nuestras experiencias con nuestros padres, muchas veces por miedo a que nos juzguen o castiguen; pero he observado cómo mantener un secreto, lo vuelve más fuerte y difícil de manejar. El Desorden de Estrés Post Traumático puede ser una condición que nos persigue por mucho tiempo si no aprendemos a procesar las memorias que causan esos síntomas. Si has sido víctima de un trauma que tal vez no estás listo(a) para compartir con tus padres, es importante que busques la ayuda de algún consejero profesional, terapista o sicólogo. La Terapia Cognitiva Conductual enfocada en el Trauma, es una técnica que te ayudara a manejar muchos de los síntomas, también puedes utilizar diarios o Terapia Narrativa o creativa, para expresar memorias y procesarlas luego en terapia. Un Psiquiatra también te puede proveer medicamentos que ayudan a manejar los síntomas del Estrés Post Traumático, pero es importante que atiendas el problema inicial para poder sanar por completo y volver a tomar las riendas de tu vida. Muchas organizaciones como los Fondos Unidos (2-1-1 en muchos estados) tiene recursos que proveen referidos a consejeros o profesionales de la salud mental. También puedes preguntarle a tu consejero escolar, doctor o en la iglesia. Sugerencia: No tienes que contarle a todos tu problema, solo pide que te recomienden a un consejero o terapista.
