What your are experience is normal for most women. We usually forget about self and totally focus on our children putting our personal wants and needs aside. So to answer your question of how do you get to know yourself I usually do a 6 session course with my client by having them answer questions such as the following in the first session: What do I love? (other than your children) What are my own needs and desires? What 3 things have I accomplished in my life that I'm most proud of? What are 5 strengths or qualities I have? What is one event that had a major impact on my life? How have that event affected my life today? For their homework assignment after the 1st session, they are asked to write a letter to self tell self what they love, cherish, appreciate and even admire about themselves. Most women feel awkward at first, but I remind them that the truth is that only to the extent that you are able to love and value yourself, you are to love and support others.

I'm truly sorry to hear that you've been through such difficult experiences. It's understandable to feel lost after going through so much trauma and focusing solely on your children for so long. Recognizing your feelings and seeking help is an important first step toward healing and rediscovering yourself. Here are a few suggestions that might help you navigate this journey: 1. **Consider Therapy**: A mental health professional can provide support, tools, and strategies to help you process your experiences and emotions. Therapy can also help you work on self-discovery and rebuilding your sense of identity. 2. **Join Support Groups**: Connecting with others who have similar experiences can provide comfort and understanding. Support groups for single mothers or survivors of trauma can be particularly beneficial. 3. **Explore Your Interests**: As your children become more independent, take the opportunity to explore your interests and hobbies. Consider trying new activities that excite you, whether it's a creative pursuit, physical activity, or learning something new. 4. **Set Small Goals**: Start with small, achievable goals for yourself. This could be as simple as dedicating time to self-care, spending a few minutes each day reflecting on your thoughts and feelings, or learning a new skill. Celebrate each achievement, no matter how small. 5. **Focus on Self-Care**: Make time for yourself, even if it's just a few moments each day. Prioritize activities that promote your well-being, such as exercise, mindfulness, or relaxation techniques. 6. **Build Your Support Network**: Surround yourself with positive, supportive people who lift you up and can help you in your journey. This could include friends, family, or community members. 7. **Reflect on Relationships**: Consider what you want in future relationships. Take time to reflect on what has and hasn't worked in the past, and think about what truly fulfills you. 8. **Be Patient with Yourself**: Healing and rediscovering yourself is a process that takes time. Allow yourself to feel your emotions, and don't rush the journey. It's okay to seek help and take time for yourself. Your experiences and feelings are valid, and you deserve support as you work toward healing and self-discovery.

I really love that you're taking responsibility for your pessimism here. There's a modern parable about two young brothers. One child is in a room full of every toy you could imagine, and he's miserable; the other is in a room full of horse manure, and he's flinging it around with joy. So then someone comes and asks the first boy why he's so miserable, because he has so much. He says that he's missing the one toy that he really wants. Then the brother is asked why he's so happy in a room full of manure, and he says "With all this sh-t, there's gotta be a pony in here somewhere!"Happiness is a state of mind, and I hear you saying that you used to be happy, so maybe this means you believe it's possible. That's a wonderful start.Research on depression shows us that it is very linked to pessimism. You say "I always see the worst end of things". That's pessimism. Life is like an elephant. If all you see is roughness, backup and walk around; the view will change. The key to optimism is to build your ability to see the bad things in life as 1. temporary (this will pass. I know how to fix friendships), 2. Specific (not involving the whole of your life), and 3. not your fault (tons of people fail road tests). On the flip side, it helps if we can see good things as 1. more permanent, 2. bleeding into other areas of our lives, and 3. something YOU created. Not taking credit for good things and blaming yourself for the bad ones is typical especially of women. The feelings you are having are temporary; you're in a slump and it's a good time to sit down and look at how you can make the picture look different. I think you know how; but you lack energy right now. If tackling this on your own isn't enough, a therapist can help you take that step back to look at the big picture and help you rebuild your natural resilience and capacity for joy. I wish you the best.

I agree; you need more care and support. No one deserves to feel alone, or like they hate themselves. We're all wonderful, imperfect, complicated people and we're at our best when we're all helping each other. I'm glad you wrote this question, because a lot of people have this feeling sometimes. I can tell that you're smart, because you seem to sense that the two things you wrote about are connected...you "not being yourself", and then how you felt when your grandma died. When Grandma died, you needed and deserved extra love and support, but the people around you didn't seem to give it to you, maybe. My hunch is that they wanted to, but that they didn't know how much you needed it, or what you needed exactly. The older you get, the more you will have to take charge of letting people know what you need. Maybe this is one of the suckier parts of being mature, but that's how it works. When you started middle school, it sounds like you changed; you got more quiet, right? That must have felt weird, to not be acting like yourself. It sounds like fear tricked you into thinking people wouldn't like you. Fear can be silly. So then, fear got you to not show yourself, and when we don't show ourselves, people can't see who we are; they don't know us as well and then they don't know what we need and they can't care for us as well either. Fear of not being liked isolated you from the people who love you. It does that to a lot of us. So, where you're at right now is because of what fear did to you, and also because when Grandma died you were already isolated so people couldn't see your pain and know that you needed support. There's a simple solution, but you'd have to be brave enough to look fear in the face and say "Get off my back!". "You're not helping me by telling me lies." Can you be brave enough to go back to your old, louder, self? If you talk to the people closest to you...tell them what you think and how you feel, then they'll be able to give you the care that you want and deserve. I wish you well as you try this!

Hi Tennessee, There is nothing wrong with you. There are many good reasons why you didn't say no. You didn't say no because you were caught off guard and unprepared; there is no place in life that teaches girls or boys how to manage it when someone crashes a sexual boundary. You also live in a culture where girls are encouraged to be cooperative and not upset people, and to put the needs of other people first. You instinctively want people to like you, and people can be very coercive sexually. You said it yourself; you "gave in". He wore you down.There's nothing wrong with you. It wasn't your job to say no. Women aren't the gatekeepers of male sexual urges. It was his job to get your consent first. He pressured you into it. A good therapist would help you to dig deep and uncover all these barriers to saying no and more. If you said no, what might happen then? What might that mean about you? What are you avoiding feeling? Unloved, unwanted, cold? What would you have to believe in order to be confident enough to say no? That you didn't have to do anything you don't want to do? That you're special, or that sexuality is special? Would you need a better understanding of what sexual assault is? I love that you want to do some work here to strengthen your sexual boundaries, and I urge a widespread conversation about what consent it. Men and women of all ages could use more of this training.

It's understandable to feel confused and upset after an experience like this. It's important to recognize that your feelings are valid, and it's okay to seek clarity about what happened. Here are some thoughts that might help you process the situation: 1. **Recognize Your Feelings**: It's normal to feel a mix of emotions, including guilt, fear, and confusion. Acknowledging these feelings is the first step toward understanding them. 2. **Understand Consent**: Consent is a crucial aspect of any relationship. It's important that you feel comfortable saying no and that your boundaries are respected. The fact that you felt afraid to say no indicates that the situation may have felt coercive or pressured to you. 3. **Reflect on Your Boundaries**: Consider what your boundaries are and how they were affected in this situation. It's important to think about what you're comfortable with in relationships and how you can communicate those boundaries in the future. 4. **Talk About It**: If you feel comfortable, consider discussing your feelings with someone you trust, like a friend, family member, or a therapist. Talking about your experience can help you process it and gain perspective. 5. **Self-Compassion**: Be kind to yourself. Remember that you are not alone in feeling this way, and it's important to allow yourself to heal without harsh self-judgment. 6. **Consider Professional Help**: If you find that your guilt and depression persist, it might be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide you with tools to cope with these feelings and help you navigate what you’re going through. Remember, your feelings are important, and finding a safe space to explore them can lead to healing and a better understanding of yourself.

Are there any times or moments in which you feel other than "empty"? Start with knowing the context of when you feel something other than empty.If there is no recent example, then in your mind, go back in time to think of when you felt something other than empty. Recall what you liked about this time, whether you were by yourself or with others, what type of activity you were involved at the time of non-emptiness.How did you come to your conclusion that your life purpose is to reproduce and die? It's not uncommon to feel a sense of emptiness or existential questioning, even when life seems ordinary on the surface. Many people grapple with these thoughts at different stages in life. It can often stem from a lack of fulfillment, connection, or purpose beyond basic existence. Here are a few things to consider that might help you explore these feelings: 1. **Reflect on Your Values**: Think about what truly matters to you aside from biological imperatives. Are there passions, interests, or causes that resonate deeply with you? 2. **Find Meaning in Connection**: Building relationships, whether friendships, family ties, or community involvement, can provide significant emotional fulfillment. Consider engaging with others and sharing experiences or perspectives. 3. **Set Personal Goals**: Having goals can bring a sense of purpose. They can be related to personal growth, career aspirations, or hobbies. Working towards something meaningful can give your life a new direction. 4. **Practice Mindfulness**: Sometimes, practicing mindfulness or meditation can help you connect with your feelings and thoughts in a clearer way. It can also help you appreciate the present moment. 5. **Seek Professional Guidance**: If these feelings persist or become overwhelming, it might be helpful to talk to a mental health professional. They can provide support and strategies tailored to your situation. 6. **Explore Philosophy and Literature**: Many find solace and insight in philosophical texts or literature that explore themes of existence, purpose, and meaning. Reading about how others have navigated these feelings can be enlightening. Remember, it’s perfectly okay to explore these feelings, and seeking understanding and fulfillment is a part of being human.

Maybe you have depression.The name of your condition matters much less than the descriptions you wrote of how you feel.Since you've observed how you sometimes interact with people and realize you aren't happy with the result, you've a very solid starting point for reflecting on your deeper wishes in relating to others.Start with asking reasons of yourself about the puzzling aspects of how you're engaging with others.Theorizing as to "why" you feel that pushing people away is "easier", and easier than what?Googling the keywords of how you feel, may open a starting point for ideas on knowing yourself and what you wish for.

You may be pressuring yourself to be the one person who fixes the relationship. This is impossible because the relationship belongs to both of you.Has he told you whether he feels about himself that how he interacts with you, is contributing to problems in the couple?Is he willing to understand what you're asking of him, without shutting down with whatever he is feeling when he feels blamed?Your feelings of distrust are the natural outcome of not being properly heard and understood. He's not willing to listen to you, so of course you're frustrated and this frustration comes out in all sorts of uneasy feelings.Willingness to hear each other in a non-defensive way, sometimes requires a couples therapist's assistance.Ask your husband if he's willing to understand, not judge you. Be willing yourself to do the same.If after trying and getting nowhere, you'll know when to stop trying on your own as a couple and to find a specifically trained couples therapists.Warning, not all therapists are trained to do couples therapy. Ask the therapist if they've had specialized training in couples therapy.Otherwise, having a referee type therapy session of, "what do you think", "what do you think?", isn't going to do anything except frustrate both of you further.Good luck!

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're in a very challenging situation, and those feelings of distrust and anxiety can be incredibly overwhelming. It's understandable to feel torn between wanting to repair the relationship and feeling frustrated and hurt. Here are a few suggestions that might help you navigate this difficult time: 1. **Take Time to Reflect**: Before discussing your feelings with your husband, try to spend some time reflecting on what specifically is causing your feelings of distrust and anxiety. Are there particular actions or patterns that trigger these feelings? Understanding your emotions more clearly can help you communicate them more effectively. 2. **Choose the Right Time for Communication**: Find a time when you both can talk without distractions. Choose a calm moment to express your feelings rather than during an argument. This can help prevent the conversation from escalating and allow both of you to be more open. 3. **Use "I" Statements**: When you talk to your husband, try using "I" statements to express your feelings without sounding accusatory. For example, saying "I feel anxious when..." instead of "You make me feel anxious when..." can help reduce defensiveness. 4. **Seek to Understand**: Encourage honest communication by asking him how he feels as well. Approach the conversation with a willingness to understand his perspective, which can help foster a sense of teamwork in addressing the issues. 5. **Set Boundaries**: If there are behaviors that are contributing to your feelings of distrust, it can be helpful to identify and set boundaries together. This can create a sense of safety in the relationship. 6. **Consider Professional Help**: If communication continues to be a struggle, you might consider couples therapy. A therapist can provide a neutral space for both of you to express your feelings and work through your challenges with guidance. 7. **Self-care**: Do not forget to take care of your own emotional well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or calm can help manage anxiety and provide clarity. 8. **Recognize Your Feelings**: It's important to recognize that feelings of distrust can stem from both external and internal factors. Try to differentiate between situations that warrant concern and emotions influenced by past experiences or insecurities. Ultimately, only you and your husband can determine the future of your relationship. It's okay to seek support while you navigate through this. Whatever decision you make, prioritize your emotional well-being and inner peace.

Since you realize that hearing voices in your head is not usual for you, then definitely there is a problematic situation happening within your awareness of who you are.if you recently started taking a new drug or increased dosage of one you already were taking, and the voices started shortly after, then yes, it is possible medication created your problem.Start by telling whoever gave you the presecription, about the problem you're having."Crazy" has some flexibility as to whether someone is this way or not.Certainly a very positive sign that you're not crazy, is that you're self-aware of a problem within yourself. And, you're responsible toward yourself and making effort to address this problem.Crazy people usually don't do responsible behaviors.

Hi Boise, I'm sorry that you've lost this love. The fact that you were planning marriage and a future tells me that you meant something very special to each other at that time. It's different now...you're not together anymore, but you can't accept this, right? Good for you for identifying that this situation is damaging your life. You've been grieving for longer than you were together. Oh, but really you've not been grieving...you're stuck still loving her instead of moving forward. Unrequited love is a recipe for eternal heartache. Let's look at some possible blocks to moving forward.It could be that there's something unfinished for you. Maybe you felt hurt and you didn't have the chance to say so, or you felt you hurt her and you didn't have the chance to make it right. Maybe there's a burning question you need to ask or something else you need to say. Maybe you want to tell her you've never stopped loving her, and see if she feels the same way. If this is the case, you have two choices, right? You can reach out and say what you need to say, or you can stop ruminating on that question and let it go. If you reach out, there's no guarantee it will go well or that she'll even respond. Maybe write her a letter and don't send it (or send it...it might be worth the risk). Use the next paragraph to help you decide. Do you know how she feels? How did it end? Did she end it? Was it ended just because of the distance, or are there more differences between you that didn't work? Sometimes people are so in love that they can't clearly see that the other person isn't in love with them anymore. Use the information you have about what she wants for her life...can you honour what she says she needs? If she's asked for distance, you would do well to honour that.A key to moving forward: look at your thoughts and where they're getting stuck. Write it down. What bad thing can happen if you let it go? Or "If I move forward, that will mean..." Keep going...what would be the worst part of that? This kind of exploring can help you identify your stuck place.It is possible that you've turned this ending into some kind of negative meaning about you or your future. As in "If this person doesn't love me, then I'm unlovable", or "No one will ever love me as much as she did". So your need to cling to her in your heart is your way of rejecting that negative message about yourself or the future. Can you find another way to reject that message? Try saying these things to yourself:I know she loved me. There is evidence of that.I was a good partner. There is evidence of that.It's part of life to fall in love and then have to move forward...I can do this and learn from it.Many people like me...that's how I know I'm lovable.It's normal to feel sad. I'm grieving a lost love.I want to move forward and not stare in the rearview mirror.I know more love awaits me if I can get fear out of the way.If this person loved me, others can too, (but not if I'm clinging to some old memory)These are the kinds of things a therapist would explore with you. I wish you well!

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It's clear that you had a deep connection with this girl, and the end of a significant relationship can leave lasting emotional scars. Here are a few thoughts that might help you navigate through your feelings: 1. **Acknowledge Your Emotions**: It's okay to feel sad, hurt, or confused. Allow yourself to feel these emotions without judgment. Grieving a relationship can take time, and it's important to honor your feelings. 2. **Reflect on the Relationship**: Consider what you loved about the relationship and what you learned from it. This reflection can help you understand your feelings better and may assist in finding closure over time. 3. **Focus on Yourself**: Engage in activities that bring you joy or help you feel fulfilled. Whether it’s pursuing hobbies, exercise, or spending time with friends and family, investing time in yourself can promote healing. 4. **Seek Support**: Talking to someone about your feelings can be very helpful. This could be a trusted friend or a mental health professional. Oftentimes, expressing your emotions and getting an outside perspective can provide clarity. 5. **Consider Professional Help**: If you're feeling persistently depressed and it’s impacting your day-to-day life, it may be beneficial to talk to a therapist or counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to cope with your emotions. 6. **Take Your Time**: Healing is not a linear process and can vary from person to person. Be patient with yourself as you work through your feelings. 7. **Open Up to New Connections**: When you're ready, try to engage in social activities and meet new people. Building new connections can help you begin to move forward, even if it feels daunting right now. Remember, it’s completely normal to take time to heal after a significant relationship ends. Give yourself grace, and take steps at your own pace.

Hi Campbell River, You say you have anger but you don't mention how it shows. Or maybe it doesn't. Are you aggressive with your girlfriend? Since you mention depression, I wonder if you're bottling it all up somewhere instead of letting it show at all. If this is the case, I admire your ability to not lash out at someone who's hurting you. However, if they are totally unexpressed, anger turn inward and shift into depression. When she yells at you, what do you do? Is this the moment that you feel the most angry? I wouldn't be surprised; anger is a normal response to someone yelling at you. Something about anger...it's often there to cover up our more vulnerable emotions. Under the anger I wonder if you feel worthless, powerless, scared, unloved. Part of the trick to reducing anger is identifying those other emotions and expressing them. You say you don't know how to deal with life, and I think maybe you mean you don't know how to deal with emotions. Lots of people don't! This is confusing for most of us. What am I feeling? Why is it so strong? I'm afraid to express it for fear of hurting someone (or falling apart, or feeling alone...). How do I know what to express and what to be quiet about? These are all great questions to ask yourself, and a qualified therapist can help you sort it all out and support you in your growth. I wish you well!

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It’s important to acknowledge your feelings and recognize that it’s okay to seek help or talk about what you're experiencing. Here are a few steps you might consider: 1. **Talk to Someone:** Finding a trusted friend, family member, or therapist to talk to can provide an outlet for your feelings. Sometimes just expressing what you're going through can help lessen the burden. 2. **Practice Self-Care:** Take time for activities that you enjoy and that help you relax, whether it's exercising, reading, listening to music, or spending time in nature. 3. **Identify Triggers:** Try to understand what specifically triggers your anger. This can help you anticipate your reactions and develop strategies to cope in those moments. 4. **Develop Coping Strategies:** Techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or mindfulness can help you manage your feelings of anger and anxiety. 5. **Open Communication:** If you feel comfortable, consider talking to your girlfriend about how her behavior is affecting you. It's important to approach such conversations in a calm manner, focusing on how you feel rather than making accusations. 6. **Seek Professional Help:** If you find that your feelings of anger or depression are overwhelming, a mental health professional can provide support and guidance to help you work through these emotions. 7. **Set Boundaries:** If the situation with your girlfriend continues to feel unhealthy, it may be beneficial to set boundaries that protect your mental health. Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. Reaching out for help is a sign of strength.

Not having support from your family for such a significant problem, is a problem itself.How about your friends, are any of them nurturing or treat you kindly when you bring up that you've got this problem?Are any of your friends willing to accommodate the fact that right now you've got panic attacks from driving and being a passenger?Maybe being and feeling accepted while you're in this current phase of your life, would help diminish the panic attacks.If no support is coming to you, then a next step would be to evaluate the relationships in your life and to develop standards and expectations of others, especially that they are considerate of your great need at this time.Its possible you are bearing the emotional burden of a lot more people in your life than yourself.If no one wants to show they care about this situation, then release yourself from trying to please and satisfy everyone's wish that you be better, while they ignore your need for their support.Be realistic in what you're able to give back to people who want to be blind to your emotional need.Thinking this way will at first raise your anxiety level from fear of losing everyone. Eventually, you'll stabilize within yourself and know that all you're asking for is some support for having a tough time. Hopefully, the others will be more responsive to you.If they don't you still know that you're being reasonable for what you'd like.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you. You're not alone in this, and there are people and resources that can support you. If you're feeling overwhelmed, it might be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional or a helpline in your area. They can provide support tailored to what you're experiencing. In the meantime, I'm here to listen. If you're comfortable sharing more about what you're feeling or what's been on your mind, I'm here for you.

I'm not sure that you don't feel emotion or that you are frightened of the depth of your emotions. From what you write, the context of your growing up years had people telling you to not feel. Little kids and babies don't remember whether or not they had emotions since birth. This is information someone told you or was part of your family system.Possibly your family was afraid of their emotions or of you knowing yours.Similarly, your comparison of being human means being monster like, is not an obvious connection. Besides, monsters are an idea, they aren't real. They embody what someone considers the worst qualities of themselves or the human species. Again, I wonder whether you've taken on stories you heard growing up about how unacceptable and bad you are.A way to start learning your emotions is to start in simple, basic ways to ask yourself what you are feeling in the situations that you believe emotions would belong.If on the first bright sunny and warm day of the year, you remind yourself to notice what you're feeling in response to this, you'll be taking one step toward awareness of your emotions.If someone buys you a birthday present, be aware of how you feel. Keep adding awareness to situations and see if this builds an ease with feeling emotions.

It sounds like you’re grappling with some very complex feelings and experiences. The sense of disconnection from emotions, coupled with the enjoyment of pain and thrill from hunting, suggests a deep inner conflict. Engaging in self-harm and finding pleasure in hunting can often be ways some people cope with feelings of emptiness or a lack of emotional connection. The authors you admire, like H.P. Lovecraft and Edgar Allan Poe, often explore themes of existential dread, the uncanny, and what it means to be human. It’s understandable that their works resonate with you, especially if you feel like you don’t fit into conventional emotional experiences. It might be beneficial to continue exploring these feelings, perhaps through therapeutic avenues that allow for more understanding and healing. Diverse forms of self-expression, whether through art, writing, or other creative outlets, might also help you process these complex emotions and experiences. Remember, seeking help from a professional can provide guidance in navigating these thoughts and feelings, helping to foster a deeper understanding of yourself. You’re not alone, and there are pathways to finding peace and self-acceptance.

Your instinct to help your daughter, is natural.How you proceed depends a lot on whether she recognizes she has a psychological and emotional problem, or if only you see this from observing her.Also, her age matters a lot in what way would be most likely to succeed in addressing the problems you describe.If you and your daughter have different opinions as to whether or not she has problems, and she is above the legal age of when you have authority over her life, then you can only suggest to her that therapy may benefit her.If your daughter is in your legal control, then you can locate a counselor nearby, discuss your situation with that person, and depending on the outcome, you'd be within your parenting right to take your daughter to a counselor.Starting therapy without willingness to do so, is risky. The person may feel resentful enough to not participate. And, sometimes the counselor is skillful enough to find a path to your daughter, or any patient's self-interest and engage them in therapy.Family counseling, regardless of your daughter's age, is another way to bring your concerns to your daughter's attention, in a therapy environment in which a counselor would be able to help distinguish the seriousness of your daughter's psychological problem, from simply a difference in viewpoints between you and your daughter, in how to handle certain situations.Also, if you believe your daughter is a threat to herself, then instead of this slower route, get in touch with the emergency psychological assessment service in your town, for a more immediate response.

It's completely understandable to feel worried and stressed, especially as a parent. Taking care of a child on your own can be challenging. Here are some suggestions that might help you manage the stress and provide support for both you and your daughter: 1. **Talk About Your Feelings**: Find someone you trust—a friend, family member, or counselor—to talk to about your concerns. Sharing your feelings can help relieve some of the burden. 2. **Establish a Routine**: Children often thrive on routine. Establishing a consistent daily schedule can create a sense of stability for both of you. 3. **Practice Self-Care**: Make sure you're taking time for yourself. Whether it's taking a short walk, reading a book, or practicing mindfulness, finding moments of peace can help you recharge. 4. **Create a Support Network**: Reach out to family, friends, or community resources for support. Sometimes having someone to help with childcare or just to talk to can make a big difference. 5. **Focus on Open Communication**: Encourage your daughter to express her feelings. This can help you both understand each other better and reduce anxiety. 6. **Stay Positive and Patient**: It’s normal to have ups and downs. Try to focus on the positive aspects of your relationship and the good moments you share. 7. **Seek Professional Help if Needed**: If you’re feeling overwhelmed, consider speaking with a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and support tailored to your situation. 8. **Engage in Fun Activities Together**: Spend quality time doing activities you both enjoy, whether it’s playing games, cooking, or going on outings. This can strengthen your bond and create positive memories. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and that you're not alone in this. You're doing your best, and that's what matters.

Congrats on the birth of your son!Was your mom's request for you to leave her house, one which she asked awhile ago or was this her greeting when you walked in the door?My question is whether your mom had some changed circumstance in her life, whether she and you discussed living arrangements prior to your son's birth, or whether nothing was talked about, you assumed you'd be living with her, she assumed you wouldn't, and the two of you didn't speak to one another about any of this.Depending on the answers, there may be clues as to handling future expectations of others, especially your mom.From what you write, the women's home is supportive of your basic daily living needs. It is good news that the people who run this home know and offer community resources.In your interactions with the staff of the women's home, ask all the questions necessary so you'll have a clear understanding of the apartment lease, anything at all that is on your mind about becoming employed and finding childcare.The point is to have all the major steps you're about to start, addressed.This way, you'll be minimizing the possibility of any sudden bad news by the women's home, told to you.Sending lots of good luck!

Congratulations on your new arrival! It sounds like you’re going through a lot of big changes right now. It’s great that the women’s home is providing support as you navigate this transition. Finding stable housing and childcare will be important steps in establishing a routine for you and your baby. Here are a few steps you might consider taking: 1. **Continue Building Your Support Network**: Stay in touch with the staff at the women's home; they can provide resources and guidance. Reach out to friends or family who can offer help when possible. 2. **Childcare Options**: Research childcare facilities in your area or look into options like local daycare programs or family members who might help, especially when you begin working again. 3. **Finding Housing**: Work closely with the women’s home to secure an apartment. They often have programs and resources to help with this process. 4. **Communicate with Your Boyfriend**: Make sure to keep the lines of communication open with your boyfriend. Discuss your needs, any support he can provide, and how you can work together to manage your new responsibilities. 5. **Self-Care**: Remember to take a little time for yourself, whenever you can. Caring for a newborn is demanding, and taking care of your mental and emotional health is important too. 6. **Emergency Resources**: Familiarize yourself with local resources available for new parents, including food assistance, parenting classes, and mental health services if needed. Transitioning to motherhood can be challenging, but with the right support and resources, you can establish a stable environment for yourself and your baby. You’re doing great by seeking help, and things will improve with time. If there's anything specific you want to talk about or need help with, feel free to ask!

Deciding whether or not psychiatric medicine is a good option can be complicated, as you have noticed, and only a person who is licensed to prescribe can give you medical advice regarding medications. While there is sometimes relief from symptoms from medication, as you have pointed out, there are often negative side effects as well. While I can't give you advice on whether or not to continue medication, I would urge you to take an inventory of the positive and negative effects that you have noticed and educate yourself as much as possible about the short and long-term costs and benefits of psychiatric medication. If you can find a doctor, psychiatrist, or ARNP who is competent in mental health, it may also benefit you to consult with them.One thing that I am wondering about is, what is your support system like, in regards to your fight against depression? Are you seeing a therapist or attending any therapeutic or supportive group? While there are many things that one can do on their own to work through challenges such as depression, psychotherapy has been shown time and again in research to be highly effective and sometimes having a relationship with a caring, competent professional who understands depression and ways of helping can make a huge difference.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. It's great that you've been able to recognize the relationship between your thoughts and behaviors and your experience of depression. Since I am not a mental health professional, I can only provide general information and considerations for you to think about. 1. **Self-Reflection**: It's important to continue reflecting on what you're feeling and your experiences. Keep a journal to track your mood, activities, and any triggers you notice. This might help clarify what aspects of your mental health need more attention. 2. **Time and Habits**: Developing good habits, such as regular exercise, healthy eating, and sufficient sleep, can play a significant role in improving your overall mood. Additionally, engaging in activities you once enjoyed, even if you don't immediately feel the joy, can help rekindle interests over time. 3. **Professional Support**: Consider talking to a mental health professional about your feelings and experiences. They can help you assess whether it's beneficial to resume medication or explore alternative therapies, such as therapy, mindfulness practices, or lifestyle adjustments. 4. **Medication**: If you find that the symptoms start to interfere significantly with your daily life, it might be worth discussing medication options again with your healthcare provider. While some people do very well without medication, others find it essential for their well-being. 5. **Gradual Change**: Transitioning away from medication can take time, and it's common to experience fluctuations in mood during this process. Make sure to be patient with yourself and recognize that recovery can take time. 6. **Support System**: Lean on your support system—friends, family, or support groups can be invaluable in your journey. Sharing your feelings and receiving support can provide a sense of connection and understanding. Ultimately, the best course of action is one that aligns with your needs, which might be a combination of therapeutic practices and professional guidance. Please consider reaching out to a mental health professional to explore these options further.

As silly as it may sound, making sure that we are getting the right amount of *restful* sleep is very important when we are feeling low. The reason for this is the lack of proper sleep significantly affects our ability to problem solve and critically evaluate our situation and can lead to a domino effect in our thinking. I know you feel that you may be losing your friendships, but what are the facts that have led to this belief? Really ask yourself, "are they facts?" or are they your perspective on events. In regards to your coping behaviours at night, it sounds very isolating and also very silenced. As opposed to the sad music, why not try all music, allowing yourself to experience the wide breadth of emotions that are circling within you. One of the other recommendations I would make would be to try and journal about some of those thoughts and fears in order to release them in a positively cathartic way. Some of the behaviours that you have mentioned are a bit more significant, though and I would recommend speaking with someone directly in the near future.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you, like a mental health professional or a trusted adult. You don't have to go through this alone, and it's okay to ask for help. If you're in immediate distress or thinking about hurting yourself, please reach out to a crisis hotline or someone who can provide support. Your feelings are valid, and you deserve to feel better.

Feeling alone and/or isolated is almost always associated with being depressed. As humans, we need connection and interaction with others in order to feel satisfied. Given that you are frequently thinking about death, I highly recommend that you see a mental health professional as soon as possible to help assess your immediate needs and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your feelings of loneliness and depression. The good news is that with proper, consistent treatment and commitment to change, things can really turn around for you. A therapist can work with you on building enjoyable activities into your daily routine, change maladaptive thought patterns that contribute to your sadness, and help with exploring what has gotten you to where you are. By learning about where your sadness originates, engaging in preferred activities, and changing your thought patterns, you should begin feeling relief from the burden of depression. What will likely result, is further opportunity to find social outlets and an increased ability to connect with others. Don't give up. Create some short terms goals that you can likely achieve and make your treatment a priority and a focus. You have already taken the first step in getting better by writing to this site. Keep on this path and believe in yourself. Best of luck to you!
I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you, like a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

It sounds like you have been a positive support for your fiancee. There is no doubt that this situation is a great challenge for the both of you. While it may feel like you are responsible for her health and happiness, it is important that you understand that you, on your own, won't be able to resolve her mental health issues. Based on what you have explained, it sounds like she needs to get a medical and/or psychiatric evaluation. Whether or not she decides to take medication is her (and your) decision, but keeping an open mind about treatment options is important. I suggest that she see a therapist on her own in order to better understand and cope with her anxiety and depression, especially given her suicidal thoughts. You would also likely benefit from therapy, individual or couple's therapy, in order to address how you are feeling and best learn how to support her and your relationship. I wish the very best for both of you and hope that things will improve sooner than later.

It's clear that you deeply care for your fiancée and want to support her during a very challenging time. It's commendable that you are actively seeking ways to help her while considering her well-being. Here are some suggestions that might be helpful: 1. **Professional Support:** While you may have reservations about medication, it's essential for her to receive appropriate professional help. Therapy, particularly cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), can be highly beneficial for anxiety and depression. A mental health professional can work with her to develop coping strategies and tools for managing her symptoms. 2. **Psychiatric Service Dog:** As you've identified, a psychiatric service dog can provide emotional support and help mitigate anxiety in public spaces. If your poodle has had a calming effect on her, it might be worth exploring the possibility of getting certified for a service dog or therapy animal that can assist her outside the home. 3. **Gradual Exposure:** Encourage her to gradually face her fears in a safe and controlled way. This could involve simple activities at first, such as stepping outside for short periods, sitting in a quiet public space with you, or eventually going to less crowded areas. It’s important to proceed at her pace to avoid overwhelming her. 4. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques:** Techniques such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, and mindfulness can be effective in managing anxiety. You might consider taking a class together or finding resources online that she would feel comfortable exploring. 5. **Support Groups:** There are many organizations and online communities where individuals with anxiety and depression share their experiences and coping strategies. Participating in a support group might help her feel less isolated. 6. **Monitoring Her Well-being:** If her suicidal thoughts or self-harming behavior continue, it's crucial to have a plan in place for crisis situations. This can include having emergency contacts, hotlines, or therapist information readily available. 7. **Educated Discussions About Medication:** While you have reservations about medication, it could be helpful to have an open discussion with her about it. Some people find that medication, combined with therapy, significantly improves their quality of life. If she's open to it, a consultation with a psychiatrist could provide more clarity on her options. 8. **Daily Routine:** Help her establish a daily routine that includes time for self-care activities, gentle exercise, or enjoying a hobby she loves, all in a low-pressure environment. 9. **Patience and Support:** Above all, continue being supportive. Your presence and understanding can be incredibly powerful as she navigates her feelings and fears. Encourage her to take small steps and remind her that it's okay to seek help. You’re a valuable support for her, and together you can explore options that work best for her situation.

It sounds like you are feeling like things are hopeless and out of control and you're not sure what to do about it. If you can find a competent therapist to work with, together you may be able to come up with some strategies for alleviating the overwhelming distress that you are experiencing and gain some insight into what may be contributing to these challenges. Additionally, a therapist may be able to support you in getting back on your feet in regards to work, a place to live, and showing up with your partner in a way that will be more satisfying to you.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It’s perfectly okay to feel overwhelmed, especially when faced with significant life changes and challenges. It’s important to know that you don’t have to navigate this situation alone. Here are some steps that might help: 1. **Reach Out for Support**: Consider talking to someone about how you’re feeling. This could be friends, family, or a mental health professional. Sharing your feelings can often provide relief and clarity. 2. **Small Steps**: Focus on small, manageable steps toward improvement. This could be as simple as setting a daily routine, practicing self-care, or making small social connections. 3. **Professional Help**: If you’re feeling very overwhelmed, it might be beneficial to speak with a counselor or therapist. They can provide coping strategies and support tailored to your situation. 4. **Explore Housing Options**: If traditional rental options aren’t available due to your past, consider exploring other housing avenues, such as shared housing, transitional housing programs, or speaking with local nonprofits that assist those in need. 5. **Job Resources**: Look into job placement services, local career centers, or online job boards. Even temporary or part-time work can help alleviate some financial stress and build your resume. 6. **Community Resources**: Check local community centers for support groups, workshops, or classes. Engaging with community resources can help you feel less isolated and connect with others who may be facing similar challenges. 7. **Focus on the Present**: Trying to cope with all that’s going on can be overwhelming. Practice mindfulness or grounding techniques to help stay focused on the present moment rather than worrying about the future. 8. **Self-Care**: Prioritize things that bring you joy or peace, even in small doses—a walk in nature, a favorite book, or a hobby. These can provide little moments of relief. Feeling lost in a situation like yours can be incredibly tough, but remember that change is possible. Taking even small steps can lead toward improvement. You're not alone in this, and there are people and resources that can help you through it.

It sounds like you are feeling very unsure and out of place and the prospect of continuing to feel as you do now for the remainder of schooling seems daunting. Without getting to know more about you and your experiences here and at home, it is hard to say what you should do, however, I think exploring these things with a competent therapist may help you to discover the answer.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time, and it's important to acknowledge those feelings. Culture shock can be a challenging experience, and it's not uncommon to feel disconnected or unhappy, especially in a new environment. However, if you find that your feelings of distress are overwhelming and not improving, it might be worth considering a few things: 1. **Evaluate Your Feelings**: Take some time to reflect on whether your feelings are primarily due to culture shock or if there are deeper issues at play. Sometimes talking to a friend or a mental health professional can help you gain clarity. 2. **Seek Support**: Look for resources at your institution, such as counseling services or support groups. They can provide a space to share your feelings and might help you feel less isolated. 3. **Connect with Others**: Try to engage with fellow students or communities that share similar backgrounds or interests. Building connections can sometimes alleviate feelings of loneliness. 4. **Explore**: Sometimes getting involved in activities or exploring your surroundings can ease the transition. Look for clubs, events, or volunteer opportunities that interest you. 5. **Consider Your Options**: If you continue to feel this way despite making efforts to adapt, it may be worth considering returning home or exploring other educational opportunities. Your wellbeing is the most important thing. Ultimately, the decision is personal and should be based on what you feel is best for you. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and that you're not alone in feeling this way.

Hi Helena,I felt a bit sad when I read this. This is a new term for me... "semi-relationship". What does it mean? I know that today's culture for young people is more of a "hook-up" culture than a dating one. Maybe that means that you develop connections to people but you keep yourself from hoping for a full relationship because no one is doing that anymore. That makes me feel sad. I hear a lot of young women (I'm not sure you're female, but that's my guess) say that they struggle with hook-ups because they can't let themselves hope for a phone call after a hook-up. Research tells us that, after a hook-up, college age women tend to feel used and unworthy, and men tend to feel guilty. I think this scenario works better for men than women, but many of both genders are left unsatisfied in the end.This is only one possible explanation for your anxiety...that your gut knows that it wants to feel fully coupled with someone but you struggle with whether it's okay to want or expect that.Maybe take a moment and listen to anxiety. Anxiety tends to try to convince us that something's wrong with us or something bad's going to happen. Anxiety sometimes prefers to stay vague (it's more difficult to refute it then), but you can try to clarify it's whisperings by asking yourself these questions: What am I afraid of? What is the worst thing that might happen here? Then what might happen, and what would be the worst part of that? Keep going until you find the very worst thing that might happen? Might someone not want you...might you feel rejected...or feel not good enough...you might get hurt?Then when you find that core fear, you can look at your life and I bet you'd find a place where that idea or fear originated. A big moment (or many smaller ones) when you actually DID feel or get rejected or abandoned or hurt. In the end, it's a feeling you're trying to avoid (not life or relationship), and anxiety is trying to help you avoid it by making you overcautious. But this doesn't work for you! Good! With the help of a qualified therapist, you can learn to talk back to anxiety and move forward in life and love with calm. confidence.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. It sounds very challenging, and it's important to recognize that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience anxiety and fear related to relationships, and there can be several underlying reasons for it: 1. **Fear of Vulnerability**: Relationships often require us to be emotionally open and vulnerable, which can be scary. If you've been hurt in the past or if you're worried about being rejected, that fear can manifest as anxiety. 2. **Fear of the Unknown**: The prospect of starting a relationship can be intimidating because it involves stepping into unfamiliar territory. You may feel pressure to meet expectations or fear what might happen if things don't go as planned. 3. **Perfectionism**: If you hold yourself to high standards, you might fear that you won't measure up in a relationship, causing anxiety about how to present yourself or how to act. 4. **Social Anxiety or Generalized Anxiety**: If you tend to feel anxious in social situations overall, it can magnify your feelings when it comes to dating. 5. **Past Experiences**: Previous negative experiences in relationships or conflicts can lead to heightened anxiety about future interactions. 6. **Overthinking**: You might be prone to overanalyzing situations, leading to increased worry about what could go wrong rather than enjoying the positives. Here are some strategies you might consider to help you navigate these feelings: 1. **Self-Reflection**: Journaling about your feelings can help you pinpoint specific fears or thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Understanding these triggers can be the first step in addressing them. 2. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices such as deep breathing, meditation, or yoga can help manage anxiety symptoms and promote a sense of calm. 3. **Set Small Goals**: Instead of jumping into a full-blown relationship, try to set smaller, manageable goals. These could include starting with friendships or casually dating to lessen the pressure you feel. 4. **Talk about It**: Continue to share your feelings with someone you trust, like your sister or another friend. Sometimes just talking about your anxiety can help lessen its hold over you. 5. **Therapy**: If you’re comfortable with the idea, speaking to a therapist can provide you with professional support and coping strategies tailored to your needs. 6. **Educate Yourself**: Reading about relationships, boundaries, and self-worth can help you feel more prepared and confident in dating situations. 7. **Romanticizing the Situation**: Instead of viewing dating or a relationship as something that must lead to significant commitments, try to see it as an opportunity for fun and learning about yourself and others. Be kind to yourself as you navigate these feelings. It's completely okay to take your time and find a pace that works for you. You don’t have to rush into anything until you feel ready.

I am very sorry for the pain you are suffering. Losing the most significant person in your life is extremely painful and breakups are often equated to a death. There will certainly be a grieving process that you go through and time passing will allow the hurt to subside. With that being said, seeing a therapist is highly recommended as it sounds like continuous support may be necessary for healing to take place. Anytime sadness causes thoughts of suicide or self harm, it is important to get help immediately. A therapist can help you by validating your feelings and what you are going through, while also working with you to move through the grieving process, adopt new hobbies, social outlets, and goals for your future. While starting over and trying out new ways of being may seem like a daunting task, it will only make things easier and give you a sense of hope and purpose for your future. With the new year right around the corner, this could be viewed as a good time and opportunity to get reaquainted with yourself and set goals related to living a more fullfilling life. Hang in there. With a support system in place and a healthy mindset, things can only get easier. Best of luck to you!

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. Breakups can be incredibly painful, especially when you've invested so much time and emotion into a relationship. It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions, including love, hurt, and confusion. Here are a few things to consider: 1. **Understanding Your Feelings**: Love is complicated, and it can sometimes linger even after a relationship ends, especially if it was intense and consuming. It’s common to feel attachment to someone you've shared so much with, even if they hurt you. 2. **Self-Care**: Prioritize your well-being. Engage in activities that make you feel good or that you used to enjoy. This could be exercising, spending time in nature, pursuing hobbies, reading, or anything that gives you a sense of joy and fulfillment. 3. **Set Boundaries**: After a breakup, it can be helpful to create distance. This might mean limiting contact with your ex or unfollowing them on social media to protect your emotional state as you heal. 4. **Talk to Someone**: Seeking a therapist can be a good step. A professional can help you process your feelings and develop coping strategies as you navigate this challenging time. 5. **Reflect on the Relationship**: Think about the aspects of the relationship that were healthy and fulfilling, as well as those that were not. Reflecting on both sides can give you clarity and help you understand why it might be healthy to move on. 6. **Identify What You Need**: Take time to explore what you want and need in a relationship moving forward. Consider what qualities you value in a partner and how those align with your ex’s behaviors. 7. **Give Yourself Time**: Healing takes time, and it's often not a linear journey. Allow yourself to feel your emotions without judgment and recognize that it's okay to grieve the relationship. It’s understandable to feel hurt and question your worth, but remember that the end of this relationship doesn’t define you. Working through these feelings with the support of a therapist can help provide clarity and aid in your healing process. You deserve to feel loved, respected, and valued.

I admire your courage for stating your view about anti-depressants. Questioning mainstream thinking and being in touch with your own views, are signs of strength and clarity in a person.As a therapist, I always tell my patients to avoid anti-depressants.Their effectiveness is in suppressing a person's mood and feelings. If someone does not know how they are feeling, then they will have more difficulty in understanding themselves, their uncertainties and hesitations, and overall, how they relate to others and what they expect from others.Anti-depressants mask how someone feels.In a crisis, temporarily taking anti-depressants may be helpful. If someone is so overwhelmed that they are not functioning, then suppressing unhappy feelings so that the person can get through a day, may be of benefit for a short while.Basically, respect and follow your own opinion about anti-depressants. Your view is shared by many. It is a minority opinion, and very valid. If you would like to shop for a therapist, ask the person on the phone, what their opinions are about anti-depressants.Ideally, you will eventually find a therapist who thinks in a way which is similar to you, or at least similar enough that you will have a sense that you are able to trust working with them on whatever you define as problematic.I hope you will have an easy and productive therapist search!

It's understandable to feel anxious about the prospect of seeking help for your mental health, especially with the concerns you have about potential diagnoses and treatment options. Here are some things to consider that might help you navigate this situation: 1. **Seeking Help is Okay**: It's perfectly valid to seek help, especially if you've been feeling this way for a long time. Mental health professionals are trained to provide support and guidance tailored to your unique situation. 2. **Confidentiality**: In most countries, health care providers are required to protect your privacy. Even if you receive a diagnosis, there are protections in place to ensure that your medical records remain confidential, especially regarding sensitive information like mental health. Generally, this information is not accessible to employers or schools without your consent. 3. **Self-Help vs. Professional Help**: While self-help strategies can be beneficial, if you're finding it difficult to cope, seeking professional support may provide you with tools and strategies that you might not have considered. Therapy can help you work through your feelings in a safe environment, and many people find it more effective when combined with self-help methods. 4. **Medication Concerns**: It's important to communicate your past experiences, such as your reaction to the medication, with your doctor. This can help them provide alternative treatments that feel safer for you. Not everyone is prescribed medication, and many people benefit from therapy alone. 5. **Treatment Options**: There are various treatment options apart from medication, including talk therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and other modalities. Your treatment plan can be tailored based on what you feel comfortable with. 6. **Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)**: While ECT is still used in some cases, it's typically reserved for severe depression that hasn't responded to other treatments. It is not a common first-line treatment and is usually used when other options have failed. 7. **Your Voice Matters**: Remember that you are an active participant in your mental health care. You can express your concerns, preferences, and treatment goals to any healthcare provider you see. If you do decide to seek help, it might be helpful to prepare a list of your concerns and any questions you have to discuss with your provider. If you're uncomfortable with the idea of medication or specific treatment approaches, be honest about that as well. The goal is to find what works best for you in your journey toward better mental health.

Having time all to yourself may be necessary so you have time to reflect on your own identity and values, become more clear on what matters most to you, and with this increased self-understanding, be able to attract people who will feel like satisfying friends.Having a relationship with someone whom you push away and are pushed away, with someone who is irritating, seems to have limited benefit for each of you.Maybe you are together from fear of being alone, and being alone is exactly what you may now need in your life in order to draw more favorable people to you.
