I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you, like a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life. You don’t have to go through this alone, and there are people who want to support you.

While anxiety can come about for many reasons, trauma is definitely one of the factors that makes anxiety a possibility both immediately following a traumatic event and later in life. When we have experienced such scary violations of our bodies - we may experience residual effects of fear for many years to come. This is normal, natural and in many ways helpful - at least initially. This fear is in some way a sign that your body/mind is taking good care of you - trying to keep you on your toes in order to protect you from anything terrible happening to you again. However, as it sounds like you know, anxiety feels awful and there are certainly ways of learning to reduce anxiety. In order to get the tools you need to manage anxiety and also understand where it comes from and how it works in your life, I would encourage you to seek professional help and check out anxiety resources online.
I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It's important to talk to someone who can help you, like a mental health professional.

Would you feel more secure in conversations if instead of talking soon after meeting someone or entering a social situation, you simply listened attentively to the other people?This way you'd have a more secure idea of what topics the group likes talking about and whether you like talking about these topics as well.Maybe you simply are in groups or situations in which you don't care for the people or focus.Start by trusting your own evaluation of your true interest in being among the groups in which you are.Maybe you simply need new and different groups.

It's completely normal to experience fluctuations in your mood and social energy. Many outgoing people have moments when they feel uncertain about what to say or simply don't want to engage in conversation. Your self-awareness is a valuable asset; recognizing these feelings can be the first step toward understanding them better. It's possible that your outgoing nature serves as a way to connect with others and fill silences, but it doesn't have to define you. Everyone has moments of self-consciousness and silence, so don’t be too hard on yourself. Here are some thoughts to consider: 1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**: It’s okay to have moments of silence or to not have the right words. Accepting those moments without judgment can help ease the pressure. 2. **Quality Over Quantity**: Focus on meaningful conversations rather than feeling the need to fill every quiet moment. Sometimes, listening and being present is just as valuable as speaking. 3. **Practice Self-Compassion**: Try to be kind to yourself during those quiet moments. It's natural to feel self-conscious, but it doesn't have to dictate how you interact. 4. **Connect with Trusted Friends**: Share your feelings with friends or family members you trust. They may reassure you more than you realize and help ease your worries about what others think. 5. **Explore Your Interests**: Engaging in activities or hobbies that you're passionate about can provide a natural conversation starter when you're feeling more outgoing. 6. **Breathing and Grounding Techniques**: If you find yourself feeling overwhelmed in social situations, practicing deep breathing or grounding techniques can help calm your nerves. 7. **Reflect on Your Outgoing Nature**: Think about what you enjoy about being outgoing. Is it connecting with others? Sharing experiences? This could help you focus on the positives rather than the pressure to perform. It's valuable to embrace both your outgoing traits and moments of reflection or quietness. Trying to balance these aspects of yourself can lead to deeper connections and a more fulfilling social experience. You’re not alone in feeling this way, and many people grapple with similar feelings.

Overwhelming fear, social anxiety and depression are especially painful because they make behaving constructively a challenge. But there are also lots of examples of folks who have successfully worked their way through this. So there is hope! In addition to the suggestion to visit your doctor (who may prescribe a medication to help you relax), there are many social service agencies who provide free counseling or take medicaid. A good CBT therapist will help you look at your thinking so that you may see how you are distorting your thoughts. Behavior is also important. Despite how you may feel: it is helpful to go out, to do things that relax you (maybe a yoga class or a meditation class?). Exercise. Diet. Eat well. Think back on the things that you used to do that helped in the past, and force yourself to do these things again. I know that this seems hard, but it beats the alternative, doesn't it? Of course, I recommend you pick up a copy of my book, Living Yes, which will help you look at these and other ideas to help you out. I hope you get unstuck soon! ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It’s understandable that the stress of your living situation and relationship with your mother is impacting your ability to find a job. Here are some suggestions that might help you navigate this challenging situation: 1. **Establish Boundaries**: If possible, try to create some physical and emotional boundaries with your mother. This might involve setting specific times when you’ll be in common areas or finding ways to limit interactions that trigger stress. 2. **Seek Support Organizations**: Look for local community organizations or nonprofits that offer free or low-cost mental health services. Many communities have resources for individuals in need, including counseling, support groups, and even job placement services. 3. **Online Resources**: There are various online platforms that offer free mental health resources, including therapy apps or support groups. Websites like 7 Cups or Mental Health America can be good places to start. 4. **Focus on Self-Care**: Engage in activities that can help alleviate stress, such as exercise, meditation, or journaling. Even small activities can improve your mood and overall well-being. 5. **Job Search**: While dealing with personal stress, it may be helpful to look for jobs that have a manageable environment for you. Consider remote work or part-time positions to ease into the job market. 6. **Communicate Openly**: If there are moments when you can talk to your mother calmly about how her behavior affects you, it might help to express your feelings. However, gauge whether this is safe and respectful to your mental health. 7. **Develop a Routine**: Having a daily structure can help you feel more grounded. Consider setting daily goals for job searching while also including time for self-care. 8. **Utilize Job Resources**: Look for job fairs, online job boards, and local employment services that can help you find job opportunities suited to your skills. Some organizations also provide job readiness programs. 9. **Volunteer Work**: If you can, consider volunteering. It can provide a sense of purpose and may help you gain experience and contacts, which could lead to job opportunities later. 10. **Reach Out**: Even if you feel isolated, try reaching out to online communities or forums where you can share your experiences and find support from others who may have gone through similar situations. Remember, taking small steps can lead to significant changes over time. It’s important to prioritize your mental health and find ways to cope with your current situation. You're not alone in this struggle, and there are people and resources out there that can help you.

Thank you for reaching out! That is a great question! As an American, I can truly say that I spend way too much time on the go! It is a proven fact that Americans live in a fast paced environment compared to Europe! I often ask myself, what if I only had one day left on this Earth? What would I do? Well, that is an easy question. I would spend it with my family! Easier said than done when we are living in a tomorrow kind of World, right? Its hard to focus on the now when we are so consumed in what tomorrow shall bring.Time management is a very important factor when learning to "live life to the fullest"! In fact, this is a required course in undergraduate college now. Everyone manages their time differently and it is up to you to decide how you would like to do this. Personally, for myself I like to keep a calendar with a to-do list. I always place my most important tasks at the top of the list. That way, if I do not get through the list, I am not stressing over the little things. When planning your day, it is important you schedule work, eat and play. A much as it is hard not to work after getting off work, it must be done. There is discipline involved in this process. If you have trouble with this, then maybe seeking out some accountability such as including a coworker to make sure you do not bring work home once your shift is over or your spouse/partner reminding you that this is a time for play and not work.These are just some ideas that I am throwing out there. Again, everyone has their own style on time management. I hope this was helpful for you. Please don't hesitate to reach out for anything further!

It's common to feel like time is flying by, especially during busy or stressful periods in life. Several factors can contribute to this sensation: 1. **Routine and Repetition**: When days feel similar and routine, our brains don't register them as vividly, making time feel like it's passing more quickly. 2. **Age Perception**: As we get older, each year becomes a smaller fraction of our life, which can make it feel like time is speeding up. 3. **Life Events**: Significant life changes or transitions can create a sense of time moving faster, especially as we reflect on past experiences. 4. **Digital Distractions**: The constant connection through devices can fragment our attention, making it hard to fully engage with the present moment. Here are a few strategies to help you feel more present and slow down your perception of time: - **Mindfulness and Meditation**: Practicing mindfulness can help ground you in the present moment, making time feel more expansive. - **Change Your Routine**: Introducing new activities or experiences can create more varied memories, making time feel richer. - **Limit Screen Time**: Setting boundaries on digital distractions can create space for more engaging, fulfilling activities. - **Reflect and Journal**: Taking time to reflect on your day or week can enhance your awareness of how you spend your time. Have you tried any particular strategies to help with this feeling?

I'm sorry to hear that you are unable to get through to your parents. It sounds like you are experiencing a great deal of anxiety that needs to be addressed by a professional (despite the fact that you are unable to at the moment). I would recommend talking with another adult such as a school counselor that can offer you support in this area. Perhaps they can work with you on your anxiety issues and schedule a meeting with your parents so that he/she may help mediate the conversation with them.If you are unable to reach out to a school counselor maybe you can try a member of the family such as an aunt or an uncle that feels comfortable addressing the issue with your parents. Sometimes it helps hearing it from a third party before the situations is taken seriously enough.Good luck!

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds incredibly challenging to navigate your emotions and experiences in an environment where you're not feeling supported. Validation and understanding are crucial for mental well-being, and it’s tough when those closest to you aren't able to provide that. Here are some steps to consider that might help you address these feelings and improve the situation: 1. **Journal Your Thoughts**: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a helpful way to process your emotions. It allows you to express yourself freely without fear of judgement. 2. **Set Boundaries**: You may want to start setting boundaries with your father and others when it comes to discussions about your feelings. It's okay to express that certain comments make you uncomfortable or upset. 3. **Seek Peer Support**: While professional help may not be an option for you right now, consider reaching out to friends or peers who may be more understanding of your feelings. Sometimes talking to someone who can relate can alleviate the pressure. 4. **Practice Self-Compassion**: It’s important to be kind to yourself. Acknowledge that your feelings are valid, and it's okay to struggle. Try self-care activities that make you feel good about yourself. 5. **Limit Exposure to Negativity**: If conversations with your dad tend to make you feel worse, consider limiting those interactions or preparing responses that calmly express your desire for support instead of criticism. 6. **Explore Coping Mechanisms**: Look into various coping strategies such as mindfulness, meditation, or physical exercise. These can help manage anxiety and build self-confidence over time. 7. **Educate Your Family**: If you feel comfortable, consider sharing resources about anxiety and mental health with your family. Sometimes, people don’t understand how to respond because they lack knowledge about these issues. 8. **Identify Triggers**: Try to understand what specifically triggers your anxiety, body image issues, and feelings of worthlessness. Awareness can empower you to find ways to cope better in those situations. 9. **Plan for Social Events**: If attending parties or dinners is necessary, plan ahead. Think about what you can do if you start to feel anxious. Having an exit strategy can help you feel more in control. 10. **Consider Future Therapy**: If possible, keep an eye out for opportunities for professional help in the future, even if it's not something you can pursue right now. Therapy can be life-changing and provide the support you need. Remember, it’s important to take care of yourself and prioritize your mental health. You deserve to be heard, and your feelings are valid, even if those around you may not acknowledge them.

I’m sorry to hear that you are currently experiencing panic attacks. I hope that the medication you have been prescribed has provided you with some relief. Unfortunately, I don’t feel that moving in with your girlfriend would alleviate your anxiety. Although you may feel very anxious about leaving her, your body is reacting to this stressful event in your life in an unhealthy manner. You may be able to render this particular situation but it’s likely that you may experience another panic attack when an additional stressful event arises. Therefore, it is essential that you address the reason for why you are experiencing panic attacks in the first place followed by practicing coping mechanisms in the case that one would arise in the future.Talk therapy has shown to be effective with those affected by anxiety along with breathing exercises and yoga. A trained therapist will be able to assist you in finding the right stress reducing method so that you can reduce the chance of another attack occurring.I wish you the best of luck! It sounds like you are very happy in your relationship and I hope you are able to reduce your anxiety so that you are able to enjoy one another.

It's understandable to feel anxious about separation, and moving in with your girlfriend may seem like a solution to alleviate that anxiety. However, it's important to consider a few factors before making such a significant decision: 1. **Communication**: Talk to your girlfriend about how you're feeling. Open communication can strengthen your relationship and help both of you understand each other's needs. 2. **Therapy**: Consider working with a therapist or counselor who can help you develop coping strategies for your anxiety. They can provide support and guidance as you navigate your feelings and any potential changes in your living situation. 3. **Medication**: If you're taking medication for your panic attacks, ensure you're regularly consulting with your healthcare provider. They can help you monitor your symptoms and adjust your treatment plan if necessary. 4. **Independence**: It's important to maintain a sense of independence and self-care. Relying solely on your girlfriend for emotional support might not be sustainable in the long run. 5. **Evaluate the Relationship**: Reflect on whether moving in together is the right step for your relationship at this time. It can change the dynamics and introduce new challenges. Ultimately, while living together might provide some comfort, it's essential to address the underlying anxiety and ensure that both you and your girlfriend are ready for that commitment. Take your time and prioritize your mental health.

You didn't say what or how many medications you've tried. Certain anxiety medications can make you feel nauseous, but I haven't heard of any that cause mouth blisters, so there may be some other underlying medical issue there. I would definitely talk to your primary care physician and whoever has prescribed the medication as well as a neurologist if you've suffered a severe head injury. There are so many medications available for anxiety or insomnia or even depression that there may be others with lesser side effects.But beyond that, have you tried any other treatments such as deep breathing or meditation? Meditation can be very effective, but it takes practice and you don't have to sit cross-legged for hours chanting "Ohm" to meditate. It's about focusing on your breath, rather than all the thoughts that are racing through your head. And when they do take your mind off your breath, simply refocus (and refocus and refocus). Like I said, it takes practice, so don't give up. You can find many sites offering different ways to meditate, so look around and see what works best for you. Like medication, you just have to find the one that works best and that might take some experimentation.I hope this helps and best of luck to you.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're experiencing these challenges. Dealing with the aftermath of a head injury and its effects on mental and emotional well-being can be very difficult. While I'm not a doctor, I can suggest some strategies that may help you manage anxiety and racing thoughts: 1. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: Practicing mindfulness techniques or meditation can help calm your mind. Apps like Headspace or Calm offer guided sessions that may be beneficial. 2. **Deep Breathing Exercises**: Simple breathing exercises can help reduce anxiety and promote relaxation. Try inhaling deeply for a count of four, holding the breath for a count of four, and exhaling slowly for a count of four. 3. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can boost mood and reduce anxiety. Even moderate activities, like walking or yoga, can be helpful. 4. **Sleep Hygiene**: Create a relaxing bedtime routine, avoid screens before bed, and keep your sleeping environment comfortable. Consider establishing a consistent sleep schedule. 5. **Diet and Hydration**: Eating a balanced diet and staying hydrated can impact your mood and energy levels. Avoid excessive caffeine and sugar, which can exacerbate anxiety. 6. **Limit Stimulants**: Reduce intake of caffeine, nicotine, and other stimulants that could contribute to a racing mind. 7. **Talk Therapy**: Consider speaking with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, who can provide support tailored to your experiences and needs. 8. **Support Groups**: Connecting with others who have had similar experiences may provide comfort and understanding. Look for local or online support groups focused on head injuries or anxiety. 9. **Natural Supplements**: Some people find relief with herbal supplements like chamomile, valerian root, or ashwagandha, but consult a healthcare provider before trying any new supplements, especially since you have had issues with medications. 10. **Journaling**: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can provide an outlet and help clarify what's bothering you. 11. **Routine and Structure**: Establishing a daily routine can provide a sense of stability and help manage anxiety. It's also essential to consult with a healthcare professional who can guide you through options tailored to your specific situation, particularly considering your reactions to medications. They may explore alternative treatments or therapies that suit your needs better. Please take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out for help.

Watching children go through challenges in their lives is difficult. On a very basic level, There exists a primal need to protect them from harm. The hard part for parents is letting them feel those challenges and working through them as they get older. At some point, there is a moment that occurs when the role as a parent shifts. Children no longer need the basics (food, shelter. water, safety) as much as when they were toddlers, but rather, their needs shift to wanting more support, encouragement, advice, and room to make mistakes. This is where the ability to communicate with them, letting them direct the sails to gather the wind needed to move, is so important. Keep the lines of communication open and be available to give feedback when they ask for it.

It’s understandable to feel concerned when your child is experiencing stress, especially if it seems disproportionate to the situation. Here are some steps you can take to support her: 1. **Open Communication**: Talk to your daughter about her feelings. Validate her emotions and let her know that it’s okay to feel stressed or overwhelmed. Encourage her to express what specifically is bothering her. 2. **Identify Triggers**: Help her identify what specific situations are causing her stress. Sometimes, just recognizing the source can help her feel more in control. 3. **Teach Coping Strategies**: Introduce her to healthy coping mechanisms, such as deep breathing, mindfulness, or physical activities. These can help her manage stress when it arises. 4. **Monitor Academic Pressure**: While maintaining good grades is important, ensure that she is not pushing herself too hard. Discuss the value of balance and encourage her to take breaks and have time for relaxation and hobbies. 5. **Set Realistic Expectations**: Help her set realistic goals for herself and emphasize that it’s okay not to be perfect. Making mistakes is a part of learning. 6. **Seek Professional Help**: If her stress seems chronic, overwhelming, or if it’s interfering significantly with her daily life, it might be beneficial to consult a mental health professional, such as a child psychologist or therapist. They can provide tools and support tailored to her needs. 7. **Talk to Her Teacher**: If appropriate, consider reaching out to her teacher to discuss your concerns. They may have insights on her behavior in school and can help monitor her stress levels in the classroom. 8. **Be a Role Model**: Demonstrate healthy ways of handling stress in your own life, as children often learn by observing their parents. Remember, it’s important to address these feelings early on, but be gentle and supportive in your approach. With the right support, your daughter can learn to manage her stress effectively.

I imagine you are trying to figure out a way to be "fair" to your adult kids. The key word is "adult". If your daughter can afford to join the family for a vacation that's great, she's welcome to come. However, as you pointed out she took a vacation by herself last year - she chose to put her resources (time off work and money) into doing that. Good for her - she did what she wanted. If she wants to budget time and money for a family vacation she will.As for feeling guilty, let me echo the sentiments already offered - vacations are lovely, but not a survival need. Your girl is in her 20s and it's her turn to provide for herself. You did your parenting - now go enjoy your vacation with whoever can, and wants to, join you!

It sounds like you're in a tough situation with wanting to support your child's plans while also managing your finances. Maybe you could explore some cost-sharing options, such as finding ways for her to save up for the trip or discussing less expensive alternatives that still allow her to have a meaningful experience. Have you had a chance to talk about her travel plans and see if there are any compromises or creative solutions that might work for both of you?
All you can do/control is work on yourself. When you have enough sense of self, you will know how to deal with your family. Therapy is an investment in yourself, which affects your family.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult situation. It's important to acknowledge the emotional toll that verbal abuse can take on you, especially in front of your child. Here are some strategies you might consider to cope with this challenging environment: 1. **Set Boundaries**: If possible, clearly communicate to your parents what behaviors are unacceptable. If they continue, try to remove yourself from the situation when the verbal abuse occurs. You can walk away and give yourself space. 2. **Practice Self-Compassion**: Remind yourself that you deserve kindness and respect. It’s normal to feel drained, and recognizing your own worth can help you cope with the negativity around you. 3. **Use Positive Affirmations**: Create a set of positive affirmations that you can recite to yourself when you feel overwhelmed. This can help counteract the negative messages you’re receiving. 4. **Seek Support**: Reach out to someone you trust, whether it's a friend, family member, or therapist. Talking about your experiences can help you process your feelings and might provide you with some relief. 5. **Focus on Your Child**: Use your love for your child as motivation. Make a conscious effort to create a safe and loving environment for them, despite the external negativity. 6. **Develop Coping Strategies**: Engage in activities that promote relaxation and self-care, such as exercise, meditation, journaling, or art. These can help you recharge emotionally and mentally. 7. **Establish a Support Network**: Look for community resources, support groups, or online forums where you can connect with others who understand what you’re going through. 8. **Professional Help**: If it’s possible, consider talking to a mental health professional who can provide strategies for coping and help you navigate your situation. 9. **Plan for Future Changes**: While it might feel like you’re trapped now, think about your long-term well-being. Explore options for moving out or seeking help to create a healthier environment for you and your child when you feel ready. 10. **Mindfulness and Grounding Techniques**: Practice mindfulness to stay present and reduce anxiety. Grounding techniques can help you focus on the moment and diminish the emotional impact of the verbal abuse. Remember that you’re not alone in this, and seeking help and support is a strong and positive step. Your emotional health is important, and finding ways to nurture it, even in a challenging situation, is crucial for you and your child.

This sounds frightening and overwhelming, and I’m glad you are reaching out for help. I can’t say for sure your children are being abused but I can understand your suspicion since there appears to be a change your children’s behavior. I think it would be important for you to keep an eye on the situation Incase you notice any other changes. If you become more concerned, even suspicions of child abuse are reportable to Family protective services. If they feel it is necessary they can do an investigation. You are doing the biggest thing for your children by being there for them and supporting them.

It's understandable to feel concerned about your children's behavior, especially if it seems like they are reacting fearfully to your discipline or concern. Children can sometimes develop responses based on their past experiences, and it doesn't necessarily mean they are being harmed. Here are a few things to consider: 1. **Communication**: Have an open conversation with them when everyone is calm. Ask them how they feel and if there's anything they want to share, creating a safe space for them to express their emotions. 2. **Reflect on Your Behavior**: Consider how you may be communicating your concerns. Sometimes, even non-verbal cues can be interpreted by children as intimidation. Aim for a calm, supportive approach when addressing issues. 3. **Context Matters**: Be aware of their experiences outside of your home. If their behavior seems to change after visiting their dad, reflect on any potential external influences or past experiences they may have had with discipline. 4. **Monitor for Signs**: Keep an eye out for any other signs of distress or trauma. If you notice other behavioral changes, such as withdrawal, anxiety, or changes in mood, it might be worth seeking professional guidance. 5. **Professional Help**: If you're genuinely concerned that there might be an underlying issue, consider speaking to a child psychologist or counselor. They can provide support and guidance on how to approach the situation. Ultimately, trust your instincts as a parent. If you feel that something is off, it's important to investigate those feelings in a constructive and supportive way.

The short answer to your question is "No" it's not okay for anyone to ever be doing this. There's a lot of unanswered questions and other factors going on here that need attention. Nevertheless, don't hesitate to seek out legal counsel and/or call 911. Ideally, your fiancé would be able to speak directly to her ex-husband and set reasonable boundaries that honor whatever legal agreements are in force resultant from the divorce and custody agreements. The fact that she's afraid to say anything to him about his inappropriate behavior, and that she hasn't been able to give you any reason for her fear, suggests possible factors of past abusive behaviors, entitlement, and/or co-dependence. I hope things work out well for all and I'm confident a skilled therapist could help all navigate how best to set boundaries and experience greater healing.

It's important to consider the feelings and boundaries of everyone involved in this situation. Generally, it's not appropriate for someone to enter another person's home without permission, even if they are a parent or family member. Your fiancé's feelings are valid, and if she feels uncomfortable with his behavior, it’s essential to address it. Encouraging her to communicate her feelings to him in a calm and respectful manner may help. Setting clear boundaries about visiting times or how to enter the home could alleviate the tension and help her feel more in control of the situation. If necessary, you or a mediator could help facilitate that conversation to ensure it goes smoothly. Ultimately, open communication and respect for boundaries are key to resolving any discomfort.

Depending on your daughter’s age, this could be a learning disability. I suggest contacting the school counselor and asking for an evaluation, once she is evaluated and depending on the diagnosis, she could be provided with treatment recommendations like occupational therapy, reading glasses, or assistance in class. These and more accommodations are enforced under the 504 act. Consider if the observations that you have done are affecting her performance in school only, or also in other settings. Observe her behavior and or her emotions and see if they change as well. Discuss these with your daughter’s counselor as well.¿Tiene mi hija un desorden mental?Mi hija está en la escuela elemental. Ella no puede colorear dentro de la línea. Mezcla las palabras cuando escribe, a menos que tenga grandes espacios, o brinca las líneas.Dependiendo de la edad de tu hija esto puede ser un problema de aprendizaje. Te sugiero que contactes al consejero escolar y solicites una evaluación, dependiendo de la diagnosis, ellos pueden recomendar tratamientos como: terapia ocupacional, lentes para leer o asistencia en clase. Estos acomodos son provistos bajo la acta 504. Considera si las observaciones que has hecho afectan el desempeño de tu hija en la escuela, o en otras áreas, también observa su conducta y emociones y repórtaselo al consejero escolar.

It sounds like your daughter might be experiencing difficulties with fine motor skills and possibly visual-spatial processing. Here are some steps you can take to help her improve her coloring and writing skills: 1. **Practice Fine Motor Skills**: Engage her in activities that strengthen her hand muscles, such as playdough, beading, or using tweezers to pick up small objects. 2. **Coloring Techniques**: Encourage her to use larger coloring tools (like thick crayons or markers) that might make it easier for her to control her movements. You can also try coloring books with larger images to help her practice keeping colors within the lines. 3. **Handwriting Practice**: Use lined paper with larger lines or special handwriting paper designed for practice. There are also apps and tools available that help children with spacing when writing. 4. **Visual-Spatial Activities**: Encourage activities that improve visual-spatial awareness, like puzzles, building blocks, or drawing shapes. This can help her better understand where to place letters and words on the page. 5. **Slow and Steady**: Remind her to take her time when coloring and writing. Rushing can lead to jumbled words and colors outside the lines. 6. **Positive Reinforcement**: Celebrate her efforts and improvements, no matter how small. Positive reinforcement can boost her confidence and motivation. 7. **Consider Professional Help**: If her difficulties persist, it might be helpful to consult with a teacher or occupational therapist. They can provide assessments and tailored strategies to support her development. Each child develops at their own pace, so fostering a supportive and encouraging environment will be beneficial for her growth and confidence.

This is certainly an important issue to look into, It is always helpful to speak with the child's pediatrician since they are most familiar with the child's developmental history. Also, children tend to regress behaviorally when facing events and interactions they feel to have no control over, this can be as simple as a loss of a pet, a recent move, death in the family, and/or as serious as sexual abuse, and other things. If you have not spoken to the school that can be a good starting point.

It’s not uncommon for children to display a range of behaviors as they approach adolescence, and some may choose to engage with younger peers. Here are a few points to consider: 1. **Developmental Variability**: Children develop at different rates, both physically and emotionally. Some may feel more comfortable engaging with younger children as they explore their identities. 2. **Social Comfort**: Your daughter may find comfort in playing with younger kids, perhaps because the dynamics are easier or less competitive. It’s also possible she is seeking a sense of safety and fun that comes with simpler play. 3. **Interest and Hobbies**: Children often gravitate towards interests that are age-appropriate for younger peers, such as toys, games, and activities that they find enjoyable. 4. **Social Dynamics**: Sometimes, changes in social circles can affect a child’s behavior. If there have been shifts in her friendships or school environment, she might be navigating those changes in her own way. 5. **Emotional Needs**: Consider if there are any underlying emotional needs or experiences that might be influencing her behavior, such as anxiety, peer pressure, or changes in family dynamics. If you’re concerned about her development or social interactions, it may be helpful to have an open conversation with her about her feelings and interests. You could also consider discussing these observations with a pediatrician or child psychologist, who can provide insights tailored to her specific situation. Encourage her to explore a variety of interests, while supporting her comfort level in social interactions.

You can "move on and not live in the past" in the context of your ex-relationship, but that does not mean moving on from your child. "Moving on" then would involve accepting the end of the relationship and developing a civil relationship with your ex-partner as far as is possible for the sake of your child's development.Generally, it's good for a functional (non-abusive) parent to spend time with his/her child, but only insofar as that doesn't cause your child unnecessary stress. That requires the two adults to act like adults with each other for the sake of their child.What's confusing for children is seeing their parents act uncivilly or manipulatively. Children also do well with routines so regular dependable visitation is preferable to random visitation or, worse, not following through on commitments.But if one person is exploiting their child to harm their ex-partner, then visiting your child in that context may be stressful to him/her (depending on what you mean by using your child as a pawn). When dealing with a hostile ex-partner, your first challenge is to negotiate rules and boundaries with your ex-partner about appropriate behavior for the good of your child. If you cannot come to an agreement, a counselor can help mediate a conversation. If that's not an option, then it may be possible to turn to family court to stipulate visitation rules (for which you'd have to consult with an attorney).

Navigating a situation like this can be very challenging, especially when it involves a child. Here are some thoughts on how to proceed: 1. **Assess Your Feelings**: Take some time to reflect on your feelings regarding your ex-wife and the current situation. Acknowledge any pain or anger but also consider your child's well-being. 2. **Focus on the Child’s Needs**: Your child’s emotional and psychological health should be the priority. Frequent and positive interactions can offer love and stability, but it's crucial to consider how those interactions are framed by your ex. If seeing your child too frequently leads to conflict or manipulation from your ex, it might complicate things for both you and your child. 3. **Establish Boundaries**: Set clear boundaries with your ex-wife about your role as a parent. Having clear communication and a structured parenting plan can reduce confusion and ensure that your child knows they are loved by both parents. 4. **Quality Over Quantity**: It may be more beneficial to focus on quality time spent with your child rather than the frequency of visits. When you do see your child, make those moments count by being fully present, engaging in activities they enjoy, and fostering a nurturing relationship. 5. **Keep Communication Open**: Depending on their age, maintain an open line of communication with your child. Let them know you care about them, and encourage them to express their feelings about the situation. 6. **Seek Support**: This journey can be emotionally taxing. Consider speaking with a therapist or counselor who can help you process your feelings and provide strategies to cope with the situation. They can also assist in deciding how to maintain a relationship with your child. 7. **Focus on Yourself**: As you try to move on and not dwell on the past, invest time in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Building a fulfilling life outside of this relationship can help in healing and moving forward. 8. **Legal Considerations**: If you believe your ex-wife is using the child as a pawn, it may be advisable to consult with a legal professional regarding custody and visitation rights to ensure that your relationship with your child is protected. Ultimately, the decision about how much to see your child should be based on what's healthiest for you both. Ensuring that your child feels loved and secure while maintaining your own emotional well-being is key.

Behavioral interaction with someone who has severe autism requires highly specialized training, both for any professional staff involved with the person and for the family members.It is an unfair situation for both the person who has autism as well as the campers who do not, to expect both sides to get along harmoniously.In order to achieve this, the campers would need specialized training to know how to respond to distress in the camper who has autism.This would obviously stretch and burden the summer camp budget as well as provide an activity which usually isn't part of summer camp for children.What you can do which may be productive in helping the camper who has autism, is to point out the interaction difficulty to the summer administrators.Ultimately it is their problem to only take campers who are able to reasonably adjust to socializing together and from what you write, the administration has overreached whom they consider reasonable camper mates.

It can be challenging to navigate the dynamics of supporting a child with severe autism in a day camp setting. It's great that you're looking for ways to engage him positively. Here are some strategies to help balance the needs of the child with autism while still addressing the concerns of the other campers: 1. **Education and Awareness**: Consider having a brief, age-appropriate discussion with all the campers about autism and different ways people learn and interact. Helping them understand that everyone has unique challenges can foster empathy and acceptance. 2. **Emphasize Inclusion**: Find opportunities to involve other campers in activities with the child. This could be games, art projects, or group activities where everyone can participate together. It may help other kids see him as a friend rather than someone who needs to be treated differently. 3. **Set Clear Expectations**: Make sure that all the campers know the rules and what behaviors are expected. Reinforce that we all have different needs and some children may require extra support. 4. **Use Visual Aids**: Besides cards to keep the child with autism engaged, consider using visual schedules or charts that can also be utilized by all campers. This may help them see that everyone collaborates to create a positive environment. 5. **Positive Reinforcement**: Celebrate and acknowledge behaviors from all campers when they show understanding or kindness towards their peer. This can help promote a supportive atmosphere. 6. **Model Calmness and Patience**: Continue to model calm behavior when interacting with the child. Over time, other campers may learn to emulate this behavior, creating a more peaceful environment. 7. **Structured Activities**: Implement structured activities that cater to various skill levels. Ensure the child with autism and the other campers have engaging, appropriate tasks to focus on during the day. 8. **Communication**: Encourage open communication among the counselors, children, and parents to address any concerns and reinforce understanding. 9. **Building Relationships**: Encourage your campers to build individual connections with the child with autism, whether through shared interests or activities, helping to break down barriers. Adopting these strategies can make the day camp a more inclusive and understanding environment while respecting the specific needs of all children involved.

Probably the best way to be supportive of your son is to tell him what bothers you about the way he's handling himself.If you'd like him to work with your suggestions then before you make critical comments be sure to validate his strong points and to recognize his natural talents.People are much more likely to take advice if the person feels the criticism is spoken by someone who respects them and isn't only critical of them.Offer your availability to talk with him if you genuinely feel available to speak with him in a non-judgmental way.

It sounds like you're in a very challenging situation with your son, and it’s understandable to feel frustrated and concerned about his choices. Here are some steps you might consider taking to help him navigate this difficult time: 1. **Open and Non-Judgmental Communication**: Try to have an open and honest conversation with your son about his feelings and motivations. Approach it with empathy, rather than as a confrontation. Ask him what he wants for his future and how he feels about the choices he's made recently. 2. **Encourage Responsibility**: Help him understand the importance of responsibility. Discuss the consequences of quitting jobs and making rash decisions, and encourage him to take on new opportunities, even if they are not ideal. 3. **Support Systems**: Encourage him to seek support, whether it’s through family, friends, or professionals. Sometimes young people benefit from talking to a mentor or counselor who can offer guidance outside the family dynamic. 4. **Set Boundaries**: While you want to support him, it’s also important to maintain boundaries. If he's living with his grandparents, make sure they are on the same page regarding expectations and responsibilities. 5. **Find Alternatives**: Suggest ways he can explore new job opportunities or interests that align better with his passions. Sometimes finding a job that excites him can rekindle his drive. 6. **Encourage Skill Development**: Consider encouraging him to engage in activities or programs that build skills and self-esteem. This could include volunteering, internships, or enrolling in courses that pique his interest. 7. **Be Patient**: Change doesn’t happen overnight, and it’s important to be patient with both him and yourself. Keep the lines of communication open and be there for him as he navigates this phase in his life. 8. **Model Healthy Behavior**: Share your experiences with choices, responsibilities, and the consequences that come with them, modeling a way of handling challenges that he can learn from. Remember, ultimately, he has to be willing to make changes and decisions for himself. Providing support while encouraging personal responsibility is key. If his behavior becomes increasingly concerning, don’t hesitate to involve professionals who can provide additional support and guidance.

You felt bad when you lied, so you told the truth. I imagine your mom was really shocked and upset - both of those things tell me you are a pretty honest person. It's possible that your mom had a big reaction simply because she has learned that her child, from whom she always assumed honesty, was capable of being dishonest. That's not awesome, but it's not the end of the world. You made a mistake - you'll make more of those in your life, just try not to make the same ones over and over again.It sounds like you and your mom are close so I can see why it would feel so awful to have her distrust you. Since you are a fundamentally honest person, the way back to being trusted is going to be simple, but may take a little time. The "recipe" is easy - say what you are doing/going to do; do only that unless change is necessary, in which case you inform others involved, and repeat. And cut yourself some slack. Your mom will recover and so will you. It's an important and painful lesson about integrity, but once learned it will serve you well.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a very painful experience. Here are some steps you can consider taking to begin addressing the situation: 1. **Reflect on the Situation**: Take some time to understand what led to the loss of trust. Acknowledging your actions and their impact is an important step. 2. **Give Her Space**: It might be beneficial to give her some space to process her feelings. Respecting her need for distance can be an important part of the healing process. 3. **Communicate Openly**: When the time feels right, try to have an open and honest conversation. Apologize sincerely for your actions and express your feelings without being defensive. 4. **Take Responsibility**: Own your part in the situation. Acknowledging your mistakes can help her see that you're committed to changing and rebuilding trust. 5. **Be Patient**: Trust takes time to rebuild. Understand that she may need time to process her emotions and feelings. 6. **Work on Yourself**: Reflect on what led to the breach of trust and identify ways to improve. This can be through self-growth, therapy, or other avenues that help you understand yourself better. 7. **Seek Support**: Talk to friends or a counselor about how you’re feeling. Sometimes, expressing your feelings can provide comfort and guidance. 8. **Show Consistency**: If she’s open to it, demonstrate through your actions that you’re working to regain her trust. Consistency over time can help rebuild what has been broken. Remember, healing takes time, both for you and for the person you hurt. Be kind to yourself during this process.

That sounds awful, and is clearly unsustainable. There are some great answers that give some guidance about what might be an underlying condition. If all physical and mental health issues are ruled out, it's time to take action. Get backup from friends or family members if you need to, but let your daughter know you are giving her 30 days notice. She needs to find another place to live within that time. If she wants to stay with you, be clear that first she has to go, with a potential to return after she has been out for a good chunk of time. Once out, she can prove to you, and more importantly to herself, that she is capable of maintaining her health and her environment. Remember, you are going to rule out issues that would make it impossible for her to be successful; if she is in good health, her staying with you and living this way is actually harming her.

It sounds like you’re in a difficult situation, and it’s understandable that you’re concerned for her well-being. Here are some steps you might consider taking to try and communicate more effectively and support her: 1. **Choose the Right Time and Place**: Find a calm and private moment to approach her when she isn’t preoccupied or overwhelmed. Make sure she feels safe and secure, as this can facilitate better communication. 2. **Use "I" Statements**: Share your feelings without sounding accusatory. For example, say, “I feel worried when I see you so tired and isolated,” rather than, “You need to get out of your room.” 3. **Listen Actively**: Encourage her to share her thoughts and feelings. Show empathy and validate her experiences. Sometimes just knowing someone is willing to listen can open up communication. 4. **Avoid Pressure**: Instead of suggesting solutions right away, try to express your concern without pushing her to change. Let her take the lead in expressing what she might need or how she feels. 5. **Offer Support**: Let her know that you are there for her and are willing to help in whatever way she feels comfortable. Whether that's going for a walk, talking to a professional, or just spending time together doing something she enjoys. 6. **Encourage Professional Help**: Gently suggest the idea of talking to a healthcare professional or therapist. Emphasize that seeking help is a sign of strength and that it can provide her with additional support. 7. **Educate Yourself**: If possible, learn about signs of depression or other mental health issues. This can help you understand what she might be experiencing and how best to communicate with her. 8. **Be Patient**: Change takes time, especially when someone is struggling. Your consistent support can be crucial, even if it seems like she’s not receptive right now. 9. **Maintain Your Own Well-Being**: While it’s important to support her, don’t forget to take care of yourself. Seek out support for yourself as well if you are feeling overwhelmed. Ultimately, your compassion and willingness to be there for her may help her feel less alone and more open to change in the future.

A lot depends on the age of your child, but given that it was a mis-used debit card, I am going to guess he's a teen? Assuming that, there are a couple of important things to keep in mind...1. That he lied about the misuse indicates he knows he was in the wrong. That's a dreadful feeling - getting caught out- and an impulsive lie may have popped out of his mouth before he thought it through (after all a debit spend is pretty easy to track). 2. Once he lied he stuck with the lie. Somewhere along the line, even though he knew that you knew he wasn't telling the truth, he stuck with his story. And as you said, it's not the first time he lied. Now it looks like a habit has formed.Going forward, when there is a dishonest act of any kind, it's essential that you set it up so your son can be truthful. Simply put, do not ask questions. If you know for certain that he has, for example, misused your debit card, say so. Asking "did you" invites him to get creative with denial; asking "why did you" implies that, with a good enough reason, he might not be in hot water with you. Instead, say what is: "I see this charge on my debit card and realize you used it without my permission". (You can only do this if you know for sure it was him but it sounds like you do). If he meets with denial, stay calm, restate that you are aware this happened. Then deliver consequences that match the transgression (he has to return the item if it's returnable or find a way to pay you back for the charge as well as any fees incurred in using it). Make it harder to find your card because he isn't that great at curbing the impulse to use it yet.And most importantly, once the consequence is delivered you have to let it go. Continuing to bring it up won't benefit him, but it does have the potential to make him more sneaky. Every time he asks respectfully to use it, whether you allow him to or not, be sure to praise him for asking nicely. "Catch" him doing it right as often as possible.Hang in there - this isn't super unusual behavior but it isn't acceptable, so address it but don't let yourself get too wound up about it.

It sounds like you’re dealing with a very challenging situation, and it’s understandable that you’re feeling frustrated. Addressing issues of trust and honesty, especially regarding stealing and lying, can be complex. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. **Stay Calm and Understand**: Take a moment to collect your thoughts before addressing the situation. It’s important to approach your son calmly to avoid escalating tensions. Try to understand why he felt the need to steal your debit card. Sometimes, underlying issues like peer pressure, self-esteem issues, or emotional struggles can lead to such behavior. 2. **Open a Dialogue**: Have a candid conversation with him about the incident. Instead of approaching it with anger or punishment, ask open-ended questions that encourage him to share his feelings. For example, "Can you help me understand what made you take my card?" Emphasize that it's safe for him to be honest with you. 3. **Discuss Consequences**: It's important he understands the seriousness of his actions. Explain why stealing is wrong and discuss logical consequences related to the behavior—like making amends for what he did. This could be through helping with chores, doing extra work around the house, or contributing to paying back any money spent. 4. **Establish Trust and Boundaries**: Talk about the importance of honesty in your relationship. Set clear expectations regarding trust and boundaries going forward. You might want to consider involving him in developing a plan on how he can regain your trust. 5. **Professional Support**: If this behavior continues, it may be helpful to seek guidance from a counselor or therapist. They can provide support for both you and your son and help him work through any underlying issues contributing to his behavior. 6. **Model Honest Behavior**: Make sure that you are modeling the behavior you want to see. Demonstrating honesty and openness in your own communications and actions can inspire him to adopt the same values. 7. **Monitor and Follow Up**: Give him a chance to show he can be responsible, and keep the lines of communication open. After some time, revisit the topic to see how he’s feeling and discuss his progress regarding trust and honesty. Remember, building trust and teaching values take time and consistency. It’s important to be patient as you work through this together.

It's understandable to be concerned when you notice sudden changes in your child's behavior or physical actions. Toe walking, especially if it's a new behavior, can sometimes indicate underlying issues such as sensory processing differences, developmental changes, or even stress. As for the messy writing and coloring, this could be associated with a variety of factors, including motor skill development or emotional changes. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. **Talk to Her**: Have an open and supportive conversation with your daughter. Ask her how she feels about her writing and coloring, and if there’s any reason for the change in her walking style. Sometimes children can articulate feelings or experiences that might help explain the changes. 2. **Observe**: Keep an eye on her walking habits and writing over the course of a few days or weeks. Note any other potential changes in behavior, mood, or activity level. 3. **Consult a Professional**: If the behaviors persist or if you have serious concerns, it may be best to consult a pediatrician or a specialist. They can evaluate her for any potential physical, neurological, or developmental issues and may refer you to a physical therapist, occupational therapist, or psychologist if necessary. 4. **Consider Environmental Factors**: Reflect on whether there have been any significant changes in her life recently (new school, friendships, family dynamics) that could contribute to her stress or anxiety. 5. **Encourage Activities**: Providing opportunities for her to engage in activities that promote fine motor skills, such as arts and crafts, could help improve her writing and coloring. 6. **Provide Support**: Ensure she has your support in managing any feelings of anxiety or frustration that may arise from these changes. Remember that many children go through phases that involve changes in behavior, but it's always a good idea to err on the side of caution and seek professional advice if you're concerned.

It's not uncommon for parents to have varying levels of attachment to their children, especially when they have a larger age gap between them. Your feelings are certainly valid, and many parents go through phases where they connect more deeply with some children than others, particularly when the youngest child is still very young and dependent. At one year old, the youngest child may require a lot of attention and care, which can be overwhelming, especially when you have older children who may be more independent and able to engage in different activities. It can also be challenging to form that bond when you're still in the early stages of parenting with the youngest. However, it's important to recognize these feelings and reflect on them. Building a bond with the youngest child may take time, and it's okay to be in a different place emotionally right now. Consider spending one-on-one time with her during play or bonding activities to help strengthen your connection. This could also be an opportunity to reflect on your feelings and seek support or resources if you feel it's necessary. If your feelings persist or lead to significant distress, talking to a professional, like a therapist or counselor, could be beneficial. Remember, parenting can be complex, and seeking help is a sign of strength.

You seem to have been a very positive influence in your kids' lives.They may have worked so hard because they understood how difficult and tiring your life was as a single mom.I feel you are seeing your kids' lives through the measurement of how much toil was in your life as a single mom.In other words, what you see your kids overlooking or not appreciating, may remind you of your wishes during the many years you raised your kids.If it helps you and is possible, then maybe you could spend more of your own time tougher with your grandkids. It's understandable to feel guilt as a parent, especially when you've had to balance work and raising your children as a single mom. Your dedication to providing for your family is commendable, and it's important to recognize the sacrifices you've made. The success of your children in building their own businesses and having support systems in place reflects the valuable lessons you've taught them about hard work, resilience, and independence. While it's natural to worry about missed moments, it's important to remember that every family's journey is different. The opportunities your children have now are also a testament to your efforts and the strong foundation you've provided. It's possible that they appreciate the sacrifices you made, and they may understand the importance of balancing work and family life. Instead of focusing on guilt, consider shifting your perspective to pride in your accomplishments and the well-being of your children. You could also encourage open conversations with them about your feelings, as sharing your thoughts can help alleviate some of that burden. Over time, they may also express gratitude for the values you've instilled in them. Ultimately, it's never too late to connect with your children and build memories together. You might find joy in spending quality time with them and, in turn, they may appreciate their opportunities even more. Embrace your journey as a parent, and give yourself grace for the choices you had to make along the way.

Oh my goodness, my heart goes out to you!! I pray you have other strong and supportive loved ones or friends surrounding you. If you are in school, please consider speaking with a counselor on site who can help give you some good coping mechanisms as well as other resources.I believe most therapists would agree that this type of behavior is indicative of emotional AND verbal abuse. And quite often the two overlap because someone who is being yelled at and demeaned is also frequently having his/her emotions preyed upon as well. Healthy Place offers us some great examples of emotional abuse which certainly fit the criteria of what you describe:Yelling or swearing Name calling or insults; mocking.Threats and intimidation.Ignoring or excluding.Isolating.Humiliating.Denial of the abuse and blaming of the victim.And abuse survivor and author, Kellie Jo Holly, offers some other great examples of verbal abuse:Emotionally Abusive StatementsYou’re so cute when you try to concentrate! Look at you trying to think.I can’t believe I love a stupid jerk.Aw, come on, can’t you take a joke?Sexually Abusive StatementsYou should know how to please me by now.I hoped you were less experienced.Stop acting like a whore.Financially Abusive StatementsYou are going to nickel and dime me to death!In what world does buying that make sense?Fine. You handle your finances. Let me know when things go to hell.Societally Abusive StatementsHow dare you spread around our private business!Let me do the talking; people listen to men.You took a vow in front of God and everybody and I expect you to honor it!Threatening and Intimidating StatementsIf you don’t train that dog I’m going to rub your nose in its mess.I will take our kids if you leave me.You’re scared?! This isn’t angry! You will KNOW when I’m ANGRY!Spiritually Abusive StatementKeep your stupid beliefs to yourself.God will find a way to get you back, and it ain’t gonna be pretty.I can feel myself being pulled into hell just listening to your nonsense!It's been my personal clinical experience that children who are experiencing the types of things you describe often say they feel misunderstood, lonely, or scared and don't want to make things worse by standing up for themselves. Even if you feel you can't defend yourself outwardly, that doesn't mean your father's awful and toxic behavior is something you should ever internalize (i.e., believe to be true) which is why I hope you are surrounding yourself with people who will speak life and positivity back over you. We are ALL worthy of respect, love, and kindness. Don't ever forget that!My love and light to you hon.Tamara Powell, LMHC

It's understandable to feel concerned about a preteen's developing sexuality and the choices they make regarding internet use and exposure to adult content. It sounds like you're facing a challenging situation. Here are a few additional strategies you might consider: 1. **Routine and Structure**: Sometimes, establishing a consistent daily routine can provide a sense of security and predictability, which can help reduce anxiety or emotional outbursts. 2. **Identify Triggers**: Keep a journal or log of when these behaviors occur to identify any patterns or specific triggers. Understanding what leads to the outbursts can help you address the root cause. 3. **Alternative Outlets**: Encourage alternative forms of expression, such as drawing, writing, or engaging in creative activities, to help her express her emotions in a constructive way. 4. **Mindfulness and Breathing Exercises**: Introduce simple mindfulness techniques or breathing exercises that can help her learn to self-soothe when she starts to feel overwhelmed. 5. **Positive Reinforcement**: Acknowledge and reward positive behavior when she handles situations well. This can motivate her to practice better coping strategies. 6. **Professional Support**: If the situation doesn’t improve, consider seeking guidance from a mental health professional who specializes in children. They can offer tailored strategies and support. 7. **Open Dialogue**: Create a safe space for her to share her feelings. Let her know that it’s okay to express frustrations, and actively listen without judgment. 8. **Play-Based Strategies**: Sometimes, kids respond better in play scenarios. Role-playing different situations can help her navigate emotions in a less stressful way. Remember that it’s okay to reach out for help if you’re feeling overwhelmed. You’re not alone, and there are resources available to support you both.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed, especially when you’re juggling so many responsibilities and facing financial stress. Here are some steps you can take to find support and improve your situation: ### 1. **Reach Out for Help:** - **Friends and Family**: Share your feelings and struggles with trusted friends or family members. They may offer emotional support or practical help. - **Support Groups**: Look for local or online groups for parents or individuals facing similar challenges. Sometimes just knowing others are in the same boat can be comforting. ### 2. **Professional Guidance:** - **Therapy or Counseling**: Speaking with a mental health professional can provide a safe space to express your feelings and develop coping strategies. Many offer sliding scale fees based on income. - **Financial Counseling**: Seek out local nonprofits or community organizations that provide financial help or counseling to help you manage your bills better. ### 3. **Community Resources:** - **Food Banks and Assistance Programs**: Look for local food banks or programs that can help relieve some financial pressure on food costs. - **Social Services**: Depending on your situation, you might qualify for assistance programs for housing, utilities, or childcare. ### 4. **Job Resources:** - **Career Counseling and Job Placement**: Look for local organizations that provide job training and placement services. They can assist with resume building and job searching. - **Remote Work and Flexible Jobs**: Explore job options that allow work from home or flexible hours which can help you balance your family and work commitments better. ### 5. **Set Boundaries:** - **Communicate Your Needs**: If possible, have a conversation with your partner about your needs for time, space, and support. Even small changes can make a significant difference. - **Prioritize Self-Care**: Remember to set aside time for yourself, even if it’s just a few moments each day to recharge. This can help improve your overall mental and emotional well-being. ### 6. **Create a Support Network:** - **Join Parenting Groups**: Look for local or online groups where you can connect with other parents. This can be a source of encouragement and practical tips. - **Playdates and Childcare Swap**: Consider arranging playdates with other parents, which can provide both socialization for your kids and a break for you. ### 7. **Focus on Small Steps:** - **Set Achievable Goals**: Break down tasks into smaller, manageable steps. Celebrate small victories to help build your confidence and motivation. Remember, it’s okay to ask for help and to prioritize your needs too. Taking small steps toward change and reaching out for support can make a big difference over time. You’re not alone, and there are resources and people who want to help.

It's understandable to be concerned when your child expresses such intense emotions, especially when they mention self-harm. Here are some steps to consider as you approach this situation: 1. **Stay Calm**: First and foremost, remain calm. Your child is likely overwhelmed and expressing extreme feelings, and it’s important for you to provide a sense of safety and stability. 2. **Talk to Her**: When she’s calm, have a gentle conversation with her about what happened. Ask her about her feelings and let her know that it's okay to express difficult emotions. Try to understand what specifically made her feel that way. 3. **Validate Her Emotions**: Let her know that it’s okay to feel upset or tired. Validate her feelings by saying things like, "I understand that you were really tired and frustrated." 4. **Discuss the Baby**: If you think that the new sibling’s arrival may be impacting her, talk about it. Explain that it’s normal to feel various emotions when a new baby arrives, and reassure her that she is still loved and important. 5. **Monitor for Future Incidents**: Keep an eye on her emotional well-being over the coming days and weeks. If you notice continued signs of distress, it may be beneficial to consult a professional, such as a pediatrician or child psychologist, who can provide guidance. 6. **Establish a Routine**: Consistent routines can provide a sense of security for children. Make sure she has time for rest, play, and one-on-one time with you, even with the new baby. 7. **Teach Coping Skills**: Help her to develop healthy coping strategies for her emotions. This can include deep breathing exercises, talking about her feelings, or engaging in calming activities. 8. **Involve Family**: If appropriate, involve your child’s grandparents in the conversation. They may be able to help support her and reassure her about her place in the family. If she continues to express thoughts of self-harm or if you're feeling unsure about how to handle her emotions, don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional. It's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to emotional well-being.

The childhood history you've described involves multiple traumatic experiences and high levels of instability, which can lead to a variety of long-term effects in adulthood. While each individual's response can vary based on numerous factors, including resilience, support systems, and personal coping strategies, common potential long-term effects might include: 1. **Attachment Issues**: Adults with such backgrounds may struggle with forming secure attachments. They might experience difficulties in trusting others, have fear of abandonment, or develop anxious or avoidant attachment styles in relationships. 2. **Mental Health Challenges**: This history may increase the risk of developing mental health issues, such as depression, anxiety, PTSD, or complex PTSD, especially related to traumatic experiences in childhood. 3. **Low Self-Esteem and Self-Worth**: Experiences of abandonment and abuse can lead to a negative self-image, with feelings of worthlessness or inadequacy being prevalent. 4. **Difficulty Regulating Emotions**: Adults might find it challenging to manage and express emotions appropriately, potentially leading to mood swings, emotional instability, or difficulties coping with stress. 5. **Interpersonal Relationship Issues**: There may be persistent difficulties in relationships, including codependency, fear of intimacy, or patterns of engaging in unhealthy relationships, echoing past abusive dynamics. 6. **Trust Issues**: Given the instability and betrayal experienced, individuals may struggle to trust others, impacting personal and professional relationships. 7. **Substance Abuse**: Some may turn to drugs, alcohol, or other addictive behaviors as a way to cope with their unresolved trauma and emotional pain. 8. **Challenges with Parenting**: Adults with such a history might have fears about their parenting abilities, potentially avoiding having children altogether or repeating unhealthy patterns from their childhood. 9. **Coping Strategies**: This history can lead some individuals to develop unhealthy coping strategies as a means of survival, including avoidance, suppression of emotions, or engaging in risky behaviors. 10. **Resilience and Growth**: On a more positive note, individuals may also develop resilience, empathy, and a strong desire to break the cycle of trauma, potentially leading to personal growth, advocacy for others, or a commitment to creating a stable environment for themselves and their loved ones. It is important for individuals with such a childhood history to seek support, whether through therapy, support groups, or other resources, to process their experiences and develop healthier coping mechanisms. Each person's journey is unique, and with appropriate support, many can work towards healing and building fulfilling lives.

Hi! I'm sorry you are having such a tough time with this situation. I have worked with a number of young adults in their 20's who have had to move back home after college , or even stay at home through the college years. Bottom line is that either way , it is so difficult when you are trying to discover who you are and what you want your life to be , to have to live at home. I have even heard much older adults clients say that when they visit their childhood home , they suddenly feel like a "kid" again . The old dynamics between adults and their parents and siblings can pop right up as if they have gone back in time and are no longer adults !I would suggest that you approach your mom and say something like "I am hoping we can talk about the best way for us to manage me living here. I really appreciate that you are giving me a place to live until I get on my feet , and I want to be respectful of you and our home ; at the same time , though, I feel like it's important for me to have more independence than when I was younger because I am growing up and trying to learn more about myself and become more autonomous. Can we talk about what might be fair rules that we can both live with ?" If she is receptive , maybe you can each write a separate list of what you think would be fair and reasonable and then compare lists and try to make compromises and come up with a list of "guidleines" that feel fair to you both . If this is too hard to do alone , perhaps you and your mom can meet with a therapist a few times who can help you to come up with some kind of "compromise contract." This is not an easy situation , but if you can approach your mom in a calm and "mature" way and suggest a planned, structured discussion that doesn't take place in the heat of the moment , your mom may be impressed by your maturity and even more receptive to working out some rules that you can both live with.Good luck !!Elissa Gross

Navigating the relationship with your parents while living in their home can be challenging, especially when it comes to establishing your independence. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. **Communicate Openly**: Have a calm, honest conversation with your mother about how you feel. Express your desire for more independence and discuss how her rules affect your life. It’s important to communicate your feelings without sounding confrontational. 2. **Set Boundaries**: Determine which aspects of her rules you find most restrictive and discuss why you believe certain freedoms should be allowed. Setting boundaries is crucial for maintaining a healthy relationship. 3. **Understand Her Perspective**: Try to see things from your mother’s point of view. She may have concerns about your safety, well-being, or lifestyle choices. Understanding her motivations can help guide the conversation. 4. **Negotiate**: Work together to find a compromise. Perhaps you can propose a trial period for more independence or suggest rules that work for both of you. 5. **Demonstrate Responsibility**: Show that you can be responsible and make good decisions. This might involve managing your finances, contributing to household chores, or pursuing your goals. Demonstrating maturity can build trust and help you gain more autonomy. 6. **Plan for Independence**: Start developing a plan to move out. This might include saving money, looking for a job with better pay, or exploring shared living situations with friends to reduce costs. 7. **Seek Support**: Talk to a friend, family member, or counselor about what you’re experiencing. They might offer insights or strategies based on their own experiences. 8. **Know When to Stand Firm**: If the control becomes too stifling and affects your mental health or happiness, consider standing firm on your needs, even if it means difficult conversations. 9. **Consider Professional Help**: If discussions remain unproductive, family therapy can be an option. A neutral third party can facilitate healthier communication. Remember, it takes time to adjust to new dynamics in family relationships. Be patient with both yourself and your mother as you navigate this situation.
